By JIM TRELOAR 
SPECIAl TO the EXPRESS-NEWS 
MIAMI — In Na zi Germa ny , 
Jews were led to the g a s cha mbers wea ring a rm-ba nds with a y ello w Sta r o f Da v id. 
Their co mpa nio ns in dea th were a no ther g ro up o f peo ple. Their a rm-ba nds ca rried a la v ender py ra mid. 
T h ese w ere G e rm a n y ’s h o m osex ­ uals. Th e s im ila rity is p ro v idin g 
American h omosex uals with a dram a­ tic and emotional argum ent in a battle th ey are waging for civ il righ ts. 
Th ey want th e sam e freedom from discrimination th at is enjoy ed by oth er minorities ■— th e sam e op p ortunities in h ousing and em p lo y m en t th at h av e been won ov er th e y ears by racial, re­ ligious, and nationality group s. 
Th is includes th e righ t to become teach ers and Big Broth er v olunteers. 
Some say it ev en includes th e righ t to m arry someone of th e sam e sex and to adop t ch ildren. 
Wh en th ey are op p osed, th e h omo­ sex uals h aul out th e gas ch am ber story and cry "F asc ist!” 
New la ws 
As a result of aggressiv e p oliticking th ey h av e, in a rem arkably sh ort time, seen th e p assage of new laws, ordin­ ances and ch arter rev isions th at sp ell out h omosex ual righ ts in 36 cities and counties — ail with h ardly a wh isp er of dissent. 
R efusing to h ire a h om osex ual is against th e law now in Detroit, Min­ neap olis, St. Paul, Madison, Seattle, 
San Francisco, th e District of Colum­ bia, and many sm aller cities, most of th em univ ersity towns. 
But in Miami, th e gay righ ts mov e­ ment h as run into unrelenting op p osi- 
.tioii from singer Anita Bry ant, known to ev ery one with a TV set as th e Flor­ ida orange juice lady . 
Iro nies 
M iss B ry a n t, wh o n e v e r before raised h er v oice in any th ing but song, is angrily defending th e righ ts of th e majority and is fast escalating a local ordinance disp ute into a full-blown na­ tional issue. It's an issue h eav y in ir­ onic content. 

One of th e iro n ie s is th a t M iss 
B ry an t, w h ose w o rst e n e m ie s will acknowledge as “ Miss Wh olesome,” is in th e middle of one of th e most sordid p olitical cam p aigns in local memory . 
Sh e is a p assionately dev oted B ap ­ tist, "born-again” wh en sh e was eigh t y ears old, wh ose day begins and ends with family p ray ers. 
Sh e’s ev ery bit as beautiful and as v iv acious as sh e ap p ears on th e tele­ v ision screen, but sh e h as an emotional intensity th e cam era doesn’t cap ture. 
B iblical a llusio n s p e p p e r M iss 
B ry an t’s conv ersation. “ Th is is my 
Geth sem ane,” sh e said, entering h er garden with th e walk th at made h er a 
"Miss Am erica” runner-up .

Riv er Auth ority , anoth er h oldout, said h is direc to rs m ay reach a decision with in two weeks.

Gath ering Co., a Coastal subsidiary .

.Antonio h as ap p rov ed it and some City 
Council memljcrs want to rescind ap ­ p rov al and go back to court.

29 2,ooo regular soldiers and 67 o,ooo 
National (juardsmen and reserv ists in th e United States. 
Army officials said Singlaub’s new assignment is comp arable with ch ief of staff of th e U.S. com mand in Korea, a p osition from wh ich th e general was reliev ed on Carter’s orders last Satur­ day , Th e ch ief of staff ranks th ird in both major commands. 
Respo nsibility 
Th e b rief a n n o un c e m e n t of 
S in g laub ’s re a s s ig n m e n t was fo re ­ sh adowed by C arter’s statem ent at a 
Th ursday news conference th at Sing­ laub would be giv en a job with “ equal degree of resp onsibility and stature," to th e Korean assignment. 
Th e Army h ad p retty well decided as of T uesday n igh t th a t S in g laub would be giv en th e Forces Command ch ief of staff job.

John Downey , who siprnt almost 
25 y ears in prison in China as a CIA spy , didn’t say directly that he was talk ing abou t him self as he detailed the “ hy pothetical” ease of a pilot captu red by am bu sh from grou nd. 
Bu t the im plication was clear. 

One way to pick u p someone by plane in a hostile are a, he told fellow law y ers at a New Hav en, 
Conn., m eeting is to drop two teles­ coping alu m inu m poles to su pport a rope that wou ld be attached by those waiting to Im* pick ed u p. Then the plane m ak es another pass to hook the rope. 

Bu t the tables cou ld tu rn, he said, if someone else happened to be on the grou nd on the other end of the rope, “ H was an am bu sh, ju st lik e in the m ov ies,” Downey said.

FBI.

Paton urges racial 'skill’ 

» Sou th African nov elist Alan Pa­ ton, one of the most eloq u ent foes of his gov ernm ent’s policy of racial separation, has warned the United 
State's not to press too hard for m ajority ru le there lest the African cou ntry be destroy ed. 

“ The greatest sk ill and wisdom are req u ired by those who wish to liring abou t changes essi'iitial to ou t- fu tu re peace,” I’u ton said in a speech at W estern M ichigan Uni­ v ersity in Kalama/.oo. 

H e r o d is c ou nt 
George'AVillig, 27, of New York, who became on instant celebrity 
Thursday by climbing to the top of 
Monhotton's World Trade Center by rope, signs on autograph after appearing on NBC's Today Show. 
The city made peace with him 
Friday by dropping the threat of a $25o,ooo suit and settling for a fine of $1.1o — a penny per floor. Mayor Abraham Beame per­ sonally accepted a dollar and a dime from Willig at a pocked news conference. — AP Wirephoto

Homegrown popcorn and pictu res of tractors are being traded for peanu ts and poetry in a third-grade 
Bu ena Vista Ga., classroom that inclu des two members of a famou s family . 
Twenty -eight elementary school stu dents are inv olv ed in the barter­ ing with 23 third-graders at the 
Blanche-Stoddard ^ 
Elementary 
School in Iowa Falls, Iowa. Vick ie 
Rogers, a teacher in Bu ena Vista, work ed u p the project throu gh her friendship with an Iowa woman. 
Her stu dents researched the his­ tory of Bu ena Vista, its crops, its geography and, of cou rse, its rela­ tion to Plains, the Georgia hamlet 
3o miles to the sou th and the home­ town of President Jimmy Carter. 
The Bu ena Vista class inclu des 
Mandy Carter, whose father, Billy , is the President’s brother, and 
Stev en Smitli, son of 
Rosaly nn 
Carter’s brother, Mu rray . 
One stu dent. 
Grace 
Mu rray , w rote a poem for the lowans called 
“Those Carter Boy s,” 
K ento n v ery ill 

In Reading, Pa.. 
Stan Kenton. w ho su ffered a fractu red sk u ll and a blood clot on the brain, necessitat­ ing su rgery , was listed in seriou s condition. 
Kenton, still activ e as a band leader at the age of 65, fell and inju red his sk u ll in a hotel confer­ ence room last week .

4 U I McCUUOUGH 

F ou r other hostages, all teachers, rem ained captiv e in the school. 
Reporters heard what sou nded lik e two rifle shots fired from the direction of the train bu t there was no im ­ mediate ex planation of what cau sed it. 
The reporters said they saw the ter­ rorists shak ing ou t blank ets and throwing ou t garbage abou t the time the sou nds were heard. 
The Sou th Molu ccans, who want the 
Du tch gov ernm ent to press their demands for the independence of their 
Pacific island from Indonesia, hav e ask ed the release of 21 fellow ex ­ tremists jailed for terrorist activ ities and a ju mbo jet to tak e them — and a grou p of hostages — to an u ndisclosed location. 
Du tch Prime Minister Joop den Uy l told a news conference the situ ation at the train was “still v ery seriou s” de­ spite the encou raging release of the schoolchildren. 
No t neg o tia ting 
Den Uy l reiterated the gov ernment is not negotiating with the ex tremists and will not agree to hostages being transported ou t of the cou ntry . 
Police and troops, back ed by m a­ chine gu n-mou nted armored personnel carriers equ ipped with infrared night sights, hav e encircled the commu ter train in flat lu sh farmland 1o miles north of this town where sev en Sou th 
Molu ccans hold 55 hostages. 
The inner secu rity ring is three q u arters of a mile from the fou r-car blu e and y ellow train. Patrols, inclu d­ ing sharpshooters, are stationed in woods on the ou ter ring. 
Among the hostages on the train are 
2o women and 35 men, inclu ding at least sev en teen-aged stu dents and a pregnant woman su ffering from thy ­ roid trou ble. Officials say she is being prov ided with regu lar medication. 
Ho t 
“Imagine y ou rself in a metal box , in the hot su n. The tem peratu re mu st hav e risen to at least 3o degrees Cen­ tigrade (1o4 Fahrenheit). The windows are closed all day ,” said one railway official describing the situ ation inside the train. 
The terrorists on the train, one of them a woman, seem more edgy than those in the school and on Wednesday and Thu rsday display ed some of their bou nd hostages, blindfolded and dressed in white — the Oriental color of mou rning. After refu sing any su p­ plies for ov er 56 hou rs, the grou p ac­ cepted hot meals, fru it y ogu rt and ev en clean u nderwear on Thu rsday . 
In the nearby v illage of Bov ens- milde, where fou r teachers —• inclu d­ ing two women — are still held, 7 6 of the released children were reu nited with their families. Twenty -six others remained in hospitals for ex amination after they dev eloped stomach ailments that led to their release. 
Bu t while the release of the children 
— and one teacher — eased the su ­ spense in this town, bitterness contin­ u ed among the area’s Du tch toward 
Sou th Molu ccans who hav e settled here. 
Fea r 
“We’v e been terrorized and we’v e had enou gh.” said one old farmer, 
Janu s Jansen, pointing to heav y secu rity which div ides his town. “ Look at what the Molu ccans hav e done to this v illage. I don’t think y ou ou tsiders u nderstand why we fear them.” 
“This can’t go on, bu t we don’t k now how to sto p it,” Ja nsen said with tears

 in his ey es. “We cou ld ask the gov ern­ ment to mov e the Molu ccans away from here, bu t that wou ld only du mp the problem on somebody else, solv ing nothing.” 
Abou t half of Bov ensmildes 3,ooo in­ habitants are Sou th Molu ccans, part of the 4 o,ooo-strong Molu ccan commu nity in Holland. Many are descendants of soldiers who fou ght on the Du tch side in the Indonesian fight for indepen- deneb in the late 194 os. They hold onto their dream of a separate homeland.

 agents became folk heroes. 
Yet Hoov er was an incu rable cu r­ mu dgeon, conserv ativ e in his way s and narrow in his ou tlook , who fiercely believ ed the words “My cou ntry , right or wrong.” 
In dissent, he saw sedition. The cry of black power, by his lights, smack ed of rebellion. The argu ment of cons­ cience against the Vietnam War, as he saw it, bordered on ou tright treason. 
Pa trio tic crimes 

He u sed his enormou s power as dir­ ector of the FBI to u phold his v iew­ points. He indoctrinated his agents u ntil they , too, saw no wrong in com­ mitting “patriotic” crimes. 
Now John J. Kearney , a crack , conscientiou s agent has been indicted for v iolating the law in the line of du ty . 
He headed a cov ert-operations sq u ad in 
New York City .

— ■■■■■■ 
Kearney .

2nd indictment

Prade.

The late J. Edgar Hoov er has giv en his name to the new FBI headq u arters, a hu ge stru ctu re across the street from the Ju stice Department. 
It is an appropriate monu ment to his memory . Its bu lk ov erwhelms the parent agency mu ch as he ov er­ whelmed the attorney general, who was su pposed to be his su perior. 
Bu t Griffin Bell does not intend to let the FBI again become the tail that wags Washington. 

Ga s pa ins 

It look s as if the great oil pipeline across Alask a will be su rpassed by a gas pipeline across Canada, with all the cost ov erru ns, produ ction delay s and env ironmental problems that hav e made the Alask an pipeline so contro­ v ersial. 
The Federal Power Commission has recommended that a Canadian pipeline be bu ilt to carry natu ral gas from the north slopes of Alask a to the lower 
4 8 stales. 
This shou ld greatly increase the amou nt of gas av ailable to American consu mers. 
Bu t bu ried in the files of the Env ir­ onmental Protection Agency is a star­ tling, confidential report that the $7 billion pipeline will cost the American tax pay ers hu ndreds of millions of dol­ lars more than necessary . 

Three large energy conglomerates — 
Arctic Gas, Alcan and El Paso — hav e produ ced riv al plans for its constru c­ tion. 
Bu t the confidential feasibility stu dy warns that it is “highly probable none of the three proposed sy stems wou ld be able to meet its proposed schedu le” and that all three proposals wou ld 
“ probably ex perience a certain amou nt of cost ov erru ns.” 
The analy sis goes on to warn that 
Arctic’s Canadian Pipeline may not work at all u nder any circu mstances. 
The idea of bu ilding the pipeline u nder harsh winter conditions, with tem peratu res often dropping to 5o degrees below zero, “wou ld prov e ba­ sically impractical and wou ld req u ire ex tensiv e rev isions or project 

A g o n izin g p ressure wa s b ro ug ht up o n Atto rney Gen­ era l Griffin Bell to d ro p the cha rg es a g a inst Kea rney. 

 abandonment,” the stu dy declares. 
President Carter mu st decide which, if any , of the three plans will be implemented. Whatev er his decision, it probably will wind u p costing the tax pay ers billions. 
The feasibility stu dy was prepared at a cost of $12o,ooo by Research Planning 
Associates. The three firms that want to constru ct the pipeline hav e su bmit­ ted their critical comments. 
Then a final v ersion will be present­ ed to the President It is ex pected to hav e “considerable influ ence” u pon the president, a spok esman said. 

Nuclea r nig htma re 

Nu clear power has been bally hooed as a cheap form of energy , which cou ld replace oil and solv e the energy crisis. 
Yet there is dismay ing ev idence that nu clear power Is actu ally ru nning u p u tility bills and aggrav ating u nem­ ploy ment. 
The story is told in a forthcoming book , “ Nu clear Power: The Bargain 
We Can’t Afford.” by the Washing­ ton-based Env ironm ental Action 
Fou ndation. We hav e obtained the raw galley proofs. 
Here are a few of the highlights: 
• The book alleges that nu clear power plants hav e had av erage cost ov erru ns of 1oo per cent. In most in­ stances, u nsafe designs and eq u ipment had to be corrected at a cost that was passed along to the u tility cu stomers. 
• The nu clear indu stry has claimed its ex liorbitant capital costs are offset by the low cost of radioactiv e u raniu m. 
Bu t the tru th, according to the book , is that u raniu m su pplies are dwindling dangerou sly . Already , the price has shot u p from $7 to $4 2 per pou nd. It cou ld reach $25o a pou nd by 1985, the book warns. 
• Becau se of soaring prices, Wes- linghou se Electric, the nation’s largest bu ilder of nu clear plants, abru ptly canceled all of its u raniu m contracts. 
This leav es 27 u tilities with no gu ar­ antee of fu tu re su pplies.

MEXICO CITY (AP) - A Sov iet jet­ liner crashed near Hav ana airport 
Friday . The Cu ban news agency Pren- sa Latina reported 66 persons were k illed and two others inju red. 
A dispatch from Hav ana, monitored here, said 56 of the 58 passengers aboard the aircraft died in the crash. 
The entire crew of 1o was also k illed. 
Two passengers, a West German and a 
Ru ssian, were critically inju red. 
Qu oting Cu ban av iation au thorities, 
Prensa Latina said the a irc ra ft crashed abou t 3,3oo feet short of the ru nway as it was mak ing its final ap­ proach to Hav ana’s Jose Marti airport. 

Cu ban au thorities immediately set u p a team to inv estigate the crash, the news agency said. 
The plane, an Ily u shin 62, was en­ rou te to Hav ana from Moscow with stopov ers in Frank fu rt and Lisbon. 
A Canadian embassy spok esman in 
Hav ana said the plane had attempted to mak e an emergency landing with one engine afire when It crashed. 
The IL82, initially pu t into serv ice by the Sov iet airline Aeroflot in 1967 , is a jetliner with fou r tu rbofan engines mou nted in horizontal pairs along each side of the rear fu selage. It accom­ modates u p to 186 passengers. 

“It will be his decision what to do,” 
Mahon said, adding that “ it wou ld be v ery difficu lt for the President to v eto the HEW bill. It contains so many programs that are highly regarded in 
Congress.” 
Mahon joined in an effort Thu rsday to hav e the committee deftte $563 mil­ lion from the labor-HEW bill. The ef­ fort lost by one v ote, althou gh Mahoii read a letter from Carter ask ing for spending restraint. 

Rep. Robert H. Michel, R-Ill., who sponsored the redu ction, was more optimistic and promised to bring the amendment u p again in the Hou se. 
Wro ng y ea r 

On the water projects, Mahon said, 
“This was not the y ear for the ex ecu ­ tiv e to get into a controv ersy ov er spending for water projects. It was a y ear of drou ght and water shortages,” 
Mahon said he is “ wholly in su p­ port” of Carter’s plan to balance the bu dget by 1981 and think s it is impor­ tant as a way of restoring confidence and speeding economic recov ery . 
He disclosed at his news conference that the defense appropriations su b- comrnitlee has agreed on $111.2 billion in bu dget au thority for the Defense 
D epartm ent, $2.7 billion less than 
Carter recommended, bu t $6.8 billion more than was appropriated for the prev iou s y ear. He said the fu ll com­ mittee will consider the recommenda­ tion nex t month.

Mrs. Letha L. Metcalf.

Bull. 
,\l issue was the v ali­ dity of the 1967 will pro­ duced by Low ranee and a lute 1975 will produced by her hairdresser, i'arlos 
Reyna. 
Reyna was left in con­ trol of the estate in the 
1975 will and Lowranee held it by terms of the 
1967 document. 
The jury ruled Mrs. 
Metcalf w as not of sound mind and was under undue influence from 
Reyna at the time of the signing of the second will. 
The ruling autom ati­ cally giv es v alidity to the 
1967 document. 

Medical testimony of­ fered in the trial indicat­ ed Mrs. Metcalf had been hospitalized almost a do­ zen lim es in the two years prior to her death.

$16o,ooo in sav ings,

Mae 
Ferguson 
Brigham.

 stalled in any eonv enienee store or shopping center, allowing persons le do their bank ing — .such as transfer money from tluhr aeeounls — without going near their bank s. 
The moratorium called for in the bill would apply to sale of the system s after March 1, 1977, and would allow for legislativ e of the study of the nia- ehities. 
Imperfect 
Cartwright and the bank ing industry contend the fund transfer system s, particularly their security mechanism, liav e not yet been perfected. 
“ There was one ease reported in 
Washington, D.IL, where $26o,ooo in eusli was transferred and they don't k now where it went,” said slate Sen. 
Don Adams of Jasper, Senate sponsor of Cartwright’s bill. 
Strong objections to the proposed two-year m oratoriu m cam e from 
Lombardino during the eom m itlee hearing. 
The San Antonio senator explained he inv ested ov er $1oo,ooo a year ago in a business v v hieli is planning to sell such fund transfer systems. 
Contract 
He said he has already eontructed iind is in the process of placing an off-premise transfer system in the 
8 o,ooo-m em ber G ov ernm ent E m ­ ployees Credit Union building in San 
Antonio. 
“ I took a gamble,” Lombardino told the committee. “ I’v e got two big bank s in San Antonio that want to use my systems. I’v e gambled my money'and time. 
“ .And here I'm being confronted with a m oratoriu m that would cost me 
$1,ooo a day. I’v e nev er seen such a moratorium of this sort proposed in the legislature behire.” 
Testimony 
Representativ es from both the Texas 
Bunk ers Assn. and the Independent 
Bank ers Assn. of Texas testified in fav or of a need to study the electronic fund transfer systems. 
“ The people selling the hardware are pushing it and we don’t think they hav e the security systems perfected,” said Don Cav ness, representing the independent bank ers. 
He aek noweledged bank s are now prohibited under the stale constitution from hav ing their own off-premises fund transfer system s installed in other businesses, but said bank ers are not trying to neutralize competition. 
Amendment 
A proposed amendment to the con­ stitution allowing branch bank ing (and off-premises fund transfer machines) has been approv ed by the legislature and will be brought before v oters some time later this year in a referendum. 
Sum Kiniberlin of the Texas Bank ers 
.Assn. testified to what he and com ­ mittee members agreed was probably the real reason for the bank ing in­ dustry's oiiposition to off-premises systems.' 
“ Our prim a ry eoneeru is really whether sav ings and loan compaiiKiS are going to get into the business that’s really the bank ing business.” 
Durwood Curly, representing the 
Texas Sav ings and Loan Assn., testi­ fied but could not say whether he sup­ ported the bill or not for the record.

Security ma y be co ming up 

 a s s o c i a t e d PPtSS 
WASHINGTON — The Ca rter a dm inistra tio n, a s pa rt o f its ta x -rev isio n pro po sa ls to be sent to Co ng ress la ter this y ea r, is co nsidering urg ing tha t inco me ta x es be impo sed o n So cia l Security a nd Jo bless benefits, the Chica g o Sun-Times repo rted Frida y . 
The newspaper said ending the income tax- free status of these ben­ efits would hike taxes as much as $6.5 billion an­ nually on retired people, their dependents and survivors and on unem­ ployed persons. 

La w kind to 26-y ea r fng itiv e 

TAMPA, Fla. (AP) - Emory Allen 
Belcher doesn’t have to worry about the long arm of the law anymore It let go of him Friday. 
A computer caught up with him this week. 26 years after he fled a convict work camp and settled down 
1oo miles away. He landed back behind bars. 
Belcher, 54, spent two days in jail while prosecutors evaluated his case and debated whether to try him on the old escape charge. They decided to let things be 
“ We’re not going to prosecute,” 
Asst. Hillsborough County State Atty. 

Tom Davidson announced Friday. 
‘The man has been in no trouble at all in the last 26 years. We feel justice would not be served.’* 
Belcher says that ever since his escape he had been using his own name, working as a cook and tile setter in Orlando. 
“ I ’m greatly relieved," Belcher said as he left the county jail a free man. “ I ’m going back to my family and to my work.” 
His Ufe on the lam was Kept secret aU those years. When he was arrested he said “ I was heartbroken.” 
His wife “ always thought I had 

 something hanging over my head. 
But I never told her what it was," he said. “ The last 1o years I didn’t think about it much. The first 16 years I did.” 
Belcher had served 1o months of an 
18-month sentence for a $75 burglary when he fled the work camp in 1951. 
He was a passenger in a friend’s car when they were stopped for a traffic violation en route to work in 
Orlando on Wednesday by D L. Ol­ son, a sharp-eyed Orange County deputy. 
While officers were checking the driver’s license, Olson said he no­ 

 ticed Belcher was fidgety. “ He seemed a little nervous," the policeman explained Friday. “ So we ran a check on him and came up with a hit — a 26-year-old warrant ... you never know what you’re going to find these days." 
The warrant from Hillsborough 
County was dated Dec. 7, 1951, ac­ cording to Circuit Court records. 
Belcher told investigators he had carved out a quiet life for himself — worked, married twice, and fathered several children who made him a grandfather. 

It added that White 
House sources say the administration also is seriously weighing a controversal $4-biIlion proposal to tax capital gains at death, forcing estates to pay income taxes on amounts by which the value of assets appreciated between ac­ quisition and the time the assets are passed along to heirs. 

It quoted sources as saying President Carter 
“ expressed interest” in these revenue-raising proposals at a recent meeting with major ad­ ministration officials to discuss tax revision op­ tions, although no decisions were made. 

A Treasury Depart­ ment spokesman de­ clined to comment on the newspaper report and noted that the adminis­ tration is “ going over the whole range of possibili­ ties on taxes and that meeting was the first of several to discuss a var­ iety of options.” 
Such tax proposals, if eventually made, would be certain to run into heavy fire in Congress. 
To become law, they would have to be ap­ proved by Congress. 

Gra na ta bo ws o ut a t pa rty 

Public Works Dir. Sam 
Granata said farewell to 
City Hall Friday after­ noon at a party held in his honor at the Public 
Works Department. 

Friday was Granata’s last day after 2812 years in city government. 

Granata, 54, served as city manager from May 
1973 to September 1976. w hen he was fired by City 
Council. 

City 
Mgr. 
Thomas 
Huebner refused to ren­ ew Granala’s contract which ends May 31. 

Granata had little comment about his fu­ ture Friday. 

“ I'll be working some­ where. I’ve been an open book for 281^ years, but 
I’m not saying anything now,” Granata said. 

He said he had no de­ finite job now. 

Granata went to work for the city in 1949 as a front office aide to Street 
Com. James W. Knight. 
FTve years later, he became public works director. 
Graduated from Tho­ mas 
Jefferson 
High 
School and Texas A&M 
University, Granata was the second native San 
Antonian to serve as city manager. 
Jerry Henckel was the first native San Antonian to serve as city manager. 
Granata will be re­ placed by Mel Suelten- fuss as public works dir­ ector.

AUSTIN 
(AP) - The Sen ate v oted F riday to sav e som e T ex an s pen n ies on their u tility bills bu t also approv ed spen din g million s in tax dol­ lars. 
It also sen t to Gov . Dolph Briscoe an am en ded v ersion of a bill he had requ ested to fight organ ized crime. 
Hou se members sen t the gov ern or a bill prohibitin g discrimin ation again st an y on e who objects to participatin g in an abortion . They also approv ed a m easu re lim itin g telephon e com ­ pan ies’ right to charge for directorv assistan ce calls, bu t it goes back to the 
Sen ate. 
The organ ized crim e m e a su re 

 prov ides sen ten ces from fiv e y ears to life for n u merou s offen ses, in clu din g arson , robbery , gamblin g an d posses­ sion of dru gs, if the offen se was com­ mitted in con ju n ction with fiv e or more person s. 
A compromise proposal drawn u p by a con feren ce committee was approv ed by the Hou se 121-2o an d the Sen ate 
21-4. 
The Sen ate also accepted, 22-6 , a con feren ce committee report on B ris­ coe’s proposal to requ ire m ore tim e behin d bars for crim in als who u se gu n s or who in ju re v ictim s in rape, robbery , kidn appin g or sex u al abu se cases.

CHICAGO (A P) - V acationers across the nation look to the highway s 
Friday at the start of the Memorial 
Day weekend, first warm-weather ho­ liday of the y ear. 

The National Safety Cou ncil esti- 

 mates a national traffic death toll of 
4o1) to 5 dd for the weekend. 
* Du ring the three-day holiday last y ear. 442 p ersons were killed in traffic accidents. Highest toll for the p eriod was 62o deaths in the 1968 fou r-day obseiwance. 

The chief als(» hop es the new Career 
Crintinal Program aimed at rep eaters w ill do some good. Under that p ro­ gram. the p olice and the criminal dis­ trict atorney will work together to bring rep eaters to trial before first offenders. 
Besides citing the need for additional cou rts, Peters p ointed ou t the Tex as 
Dep artment of Corrections needs more 
Jail sp ace to hou se conv icted crimin­ als. lie noted the Tex as p rison p op u ­ lation has increased in 1o y ears from 
16,ooo to 24.ooo p risoners, bu t the sy s­ tem hasn’t had a comp arable increase in jail ex p ansion. 
Disa ppo intment 
Peters ex p ressed disap p ointment a bill to deny bail to rep eater defendants at the ju d ge 's discretion ap p ears headed for the legislativ e gra\ey ard. 
In argu ing for incarceration of re­ p eaters, Peters observ ed: 
“ A locked-u p criminal doesn’t com­ mit mu ch crime.” 

He also noted all too often too mu ch concern is show n for the defendant and 
Ids rights to the ex clu sion of the rights of the v ictim. 
Discu ssing rehat)ilitation, f*elers l ommented officials ha\ en’l had too mu ch su ccess “ in making good p eop le ou t of bad p eop U'.” 
Ex pressed a la rm 

A San Antonio p oliceman since 1941 and chief since 1971, Peters ex jiressed alarm at the increase of women, p ar­ ticu larly female ju v eniles, inv olv ed in crime. 
He said he didn’t know if it was du e to the change in the lifesty le, women’s liberation or a retu rn of the Bonnie and Cly de sy ndrome. 
On the good side of the ledger, 
Peters said, crimes of a v iolent natu re are down in San Antonio. On the bad side, he added, bu rglaries and thefts are u p . 
While San Antonio is the nation’s 
1oth largest city . Peters said it ranked 
39th in the nation in robberies last y ear and 29th in rap es. 
On the credit side for the p olice de- 

 p artm ent, the chief rep orted p olice cleared 89 p er cent of the mu rders in 
San .Antonio last y ear, comp ared to the national clearance av erage of 78 p er cent; cleared 75 p er cent of the rap es, comp ared to the national a\erage of 5 1, and brok<‘ 42 p er cent of the robberies, well abo\e the national a\erage of 27. 
Contrary to p u blic op inion, Peters said. 7o p er cent of the bu rglaries are committed du ring day light hou rs. 
Added deterrent 
Asked his op inion of Neighborhood liangers, F’eters said any added deter­ rent to crime is good. 
In answer to another q u estion. 
Peters said the city cou ld u se more p olice officers bu t he sy mp athizes with 
City Mgr. Tom Hu ebner’s p roblems. 
He ex p lained Hu ebner has only ,so many dollars to sp end on so many p rojects while stav ing within his bu d- 

■ 
He said the manager su ggested to him he p u t more officers now on desk jobs or at headq u arters into the field. 
Peters said he p robalily w ill be hiring civ ilians at less p ay to do sojne jobs now being p erformed by officers. 
A oO S TIN H O NETO 
. forces crush up rising 
Ang o la units crush co up by ex trem ists 

JOHANNESBURG, Sou th Africa (AP) — Angola’s 
Marx i.st President Agosthino Neto annou nced Friday that his forces had cru shed a rev olt by army ex ­ tremists after street fighting that killed many men and women. 
In a radio address moriitort*d here. Neto gav e no details of the fighting bu t said “ drastic measu res’’ wou ld be taken to p rev ent fu rther disorders in his central African cou ntry . 
Neto identified the cou p lea<lers as former Interior 
Minister Nilo Alv es and former p iditical commissar 
Jo.se Van Du nem, jailed since last Satu rday when they were p u rged from the ru ling Pop u lar Front for the Liberation of Angola — MPLA. 
Western observ iTs say tlu > two are p ro-Moscow hardliners (» p p itsed to Nelo’s p lans for attracting 
Western inv estments and redu cing dep i'iidence on the Sov iet bloc. 
Neto said the rebels had “ m isinterp reted” his ideology and that those resp onsible for the rev olt wou ld lie p u nished “ with u tmost sev erity .” 
Alv es po ssible v ictim 
In Portu gal, the national news agency ANOP retiorted Alv es may hav e been killed in the fighting and said official Angolan sp okesmen wou ld neither confirm nor deny ru mors he was dead. 
There was no indication whether Neto’s Sov iet adv isers or the 1o,oo(1-15,(1oo i’u ban troop s stationed in the former Portu gu ese colony p lay ed any p art in the day ’s ev ents. The Cu bans remained in Angola after help ing the MPLA defeat two p ro-Western grou p s in the 1975 Angolan civ il war.

Tanju g q u oted a Cu ban soldier checking identifii-a- tion p ap ers as say ing “ the reaction has been ov er­ come, what else.”

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS— Saturday Moy 28 1977 
SINGLAUB 
Continued from Page lA obvious feeling among some Pentagon leaders that Singlaub could have ex­ pressed himself more circumspectly. 
Singlaub was sacked after the Wa­ shington Post quoted him as saying the withdrawal of U.S. ground troops on the schedule laid out by Carter “ will lead to war.” 
Announcement of Singlaub’s new job was expected Thursday, but apparent­ ly was held up while Defense Secretary 
Harold Brown discussed the matter with Gen. Bernard W. Rogers, Army chief of staff. 
Some sources believe that Carter’s statement that Singlaub would get a job of equal responsibility and stature made it virtually impossible to give the general a lower grade assignment. 
Rogers said that Singlaub, who has returned to Korea to take care of some personal matters, will move into the 
Forces Command slot on .June 27. The 
Forces Command Headquarters is at 
Fort McPherson, Atlanta. 
Singlaub will be filling a vacancy created by the promotion of Maj. Gen. 
John Q. Henion, now Forces Command chief of staff, to three stars and to command of the 9th Corps in Japan. 

SETTLEMENT 

M A J . G E N . J O H N S IN G L A U B 
. . . b ig job

 must approve the settlement before it can become effective. 
Meanwhile. LCRA is proceeding on tw(t tracks, Gen. Mgr. Charit« Herring said. suit by Lt'KA against Coastal was overturni'd recently by the Texas 
Supreme Court. 
Motion 
Heri'ing said a motion for a rehear­ ing, supported by San Antonio and the attorney general, has been filed. 
While awaiting a ruling on that mo­ tion, Herring said he plans to call 
CCRA customers together within two weeks to discuss options. LCRA is an 
(‘ksLtrical wholesaler. 
When the Supreme Court ruled against LCRA it also said the Te.xas 
Railroad Commission should set a permanent rate which Lo-Vaca can charge its customers. The RRC has set hearings for mid-July. 
Tom Berg, San Antonio City Public 
Service board chairman who attended 
Friday’s meeting, said those hearings could prove the most crucial. The 

RRC, he said, has never fully exercised its authority. 
But the RRC has been assuming when it set a permanent rate for Lo- 
Vaca. which operates under a tempor­ ary one set in 1973, customers would have agreed to something.

Charles B. W right, na­ tional president of the 
N ational Pan Hellenic 
Council, will guest speaker to the organi­ zation’s San Antonio chapter at 7:3o p.m.

Panama 
Canal accord 

Abortion bill falls to committee vote 

 nearer 

WASHINGTON (A P) 
— The United States and 
Panama may be near a breakthrough in their negotiations for a new 
Canal Zone treaty, an in­ formed U.S. source said 
Friday. 
Cooperation between the two sides has been remarkably good and the progress gratifying dur­ ing the current round of negotiations, the longest 
.since the talks began 13 years ago, the informant said. 
The source, who requested anonymity, said that none of the major problems dividing the two sides have been resolved but added that the spirit of the talks seems to augur well for the future. 

Resumed 

The talks resumed here on May 9 after a 
2Vz-inonth recess. They almost broke down at one point as neither side seemed willing to back down from its previous positions, the informant said. 
But both countries have shown a new flex­ ibility since then, and the source said they soon will be prepared to discuss the question of economic benefits for Panama. 
This is regarded as a major step forward since 
Panama has always in­ sisted that this issue be dealt with last. Panama has been receiving some 
$2 million annually and both countries agree that 
Panama is entitled to a much higher figure in the new treaty. 
Another stumbling block has been agreement on a formula which would assure, without infringing on 
Panamanian sovereign­ ty, the canal’s neutrality once Panama assumes control of the waterway. 

Control 

The talks are aimed at giving 
Panama a gradually increasing role in the operation and defen.se of the canal for a specified period and full operational control even­ tually — perhaps by the year 2ooo. 
A new treaty is given virtually no chance of 
Senate ratification unless 
Panama agrees to run the canal in a non-dis* criminatory manner, guaranteeing access to all natiuas 

AUSTIN 
(AP) - A bill to regulate abortions in Texas has met its apparent death in a 
Senate committee after spon­ sors failed to get enough votes to send it to the Senate floor. 
The bill, which would outlaw abortions in Texas after the 
22nd week of pregnancy unless the procedure was necessary to stop the serious injury or death of the mother, was approved 5-4 by the Senate Jurisprudence 
Committee, two votes shy of the seven needed. 
Four members of the com­ mittee were absent. 
Chairman A, R. Schwartz. 
D-Galveston, who voted against the measure, said the commit­ tee would not meet again before the legislature’s dead­ line midnight Monday, which seals the bill’s fate. 
“ I gave them the vote,” said 
S diwartz. “ I gave them the time to get their votes here and their votes were not here. I can’t do anything about that.” 
The proposal, authored by 
Rep. Tim Von Dohlen, D- 
Goliad, passed the House 1oo-34 on May 15 after a lengthy, emotional debate. 
Atty. Gen. John Hill ruled 
Thursday that four provisions 
2 bills helpful to 
S, A, pass 

E X P R ESS C A P IT O l BU REAU 
.AUSTIN 
Two pieces 
‘of legislation that will help uplift San Antonio’s appearances and mass transit system passed the 
Senate and were sent to the governor Friday. 
HB2o28 by Rep. Matt 
García of San Antonio will authorize the city to collect taxes from certain sections inside urban renewal projects upon the request of the pro­ perty owners. 
The tax collections would be used to make further improvements to the property. 
Garcia’s bill was spon­ sored in the Senate by 
Sen. John Traeger of Se- guin. 
HB657, sponsored in the House by Rep. Bill 
Blythe of Houston, af­ fects Harris and Bexar 
Counties. 
It will allow the cities of Houston and San An­ tonio the option of utilizing their sales tax rebates from the state for the maintenance and operation of mass transit systems. 

 in the bill are possibly uncon­ stitutional when weighed against U.S. Supreme Court decisions on the subject. 
“ The amendments that we will present will place the bill in a position where there can be no question of constitutionali­ ty,” Von Dohlen told the com­ mittee. 
In an opinion, Hill objected to the bill’s definition of “ viabili­ ty,” the time when the unborn fetus might survive outside the womb, as being the 22nd week of pregnancy. 
Hill said the Supreme Court ruled in 1976 that a legislature or the courts could not make such a medical decision and would probably not permit the definition of viability contained in the bill. 
A related provision that requires physicians to attempt to preserve the life of a fetus after 22 weeks is also unconsti­ tutional, Hill said, since it also stems from a legislative defin­ ition of viability. 
Hill also said the high court would object to provisions prohibiting saline abortions and requiring a positive preg­ nancy test be required before an abortion can be performed. 

 week to take the issue back to court. It was one vote short of succeeding and is on the table. 

Webb said he wanted assurances 
Lo-Vaca will relocate its headquarters to San Antonio as part of the settle­ ment. Lo-Vaca has said it would and 
Webb apparently was reassured Fri­ day. 

 mittee also added $65 million to deve­ lop a non-nuclear version of the battlefield Lance missile, which the 
Defense Department has contended was unnecessary. 
The addition, if enacted into law, would keep another LTV production line open. It may also make foreign sales possible, for Israel has expressed interest in such a missile. 
The panel also substituted its own judgment for the reserves, and $44 million for additional Naval reserve strentgth. 
The bill’s total of $6.8 billion over the amount appropriated for the current fiscal year adopts all major weapons requests, includes the controversial 
B-1 bomber, on which Carter is ex­ pected to make a decision on whether to go ahead on full production next month, and 18 new ships — a nuclear powered cruiser, two Trident submar­ ines and one additional SSN688 attack submarine of the type Carter sailed on 
Friday off Florida. 
The subcommittee also included 
$193.8 million in long lead time funding for a nuclear powered cruiser. 

Cuts 

Cuts totaling $391 million in various requests by the intelligence communi­ ty were recommended, but Mahon said most of those reductions involved new equipment, not operations. 
The subcommittee also called for a one-year moratorium on additional contracting out of services by the De­ fense Department. The American Fe­ deration of Government Employees has been very critical of this practice, which it contends costs union members jobs in base maintenance, mess hall operations, computer work and other areas. 
HUD raises 
FHA rates 

WASHINGTON (A P) - The max­ imum allowable interest rate for 
Federal Housing Administration-in­ sured single-family mortgage loans will rise from 8 per cent to 8.5 per cent next Tuesday, the Department of 
Housing and Urban Development an­ nounced Friday.

C arter’s plans fo r co al use 

Son A ntonio EXPRESS-NEW S— S o to rd a y M o y 2 8 l 9 7 7 
P o g e T l-A 

 called V ag u e’ 

WASHINGTON (A P) 
— P resid en t (’a r te r ’s p lans for increased use of coal w ere attacked 
Friday as vague, a threat to clean air, and lacking in facts and figures to show how and where they can be imp lemented. 
Rep . Toby Moffett, D- 
Conn., told 
F ed eral 
Energy A d m in istrato r 
John F. O’Leary and En­ vironm ental Protection 
Agency head Douglas M. 
Costle that “we’re try ing to bend over backward, but it’s becom ing ex ­ tremely difficult.” 
Moffett and Chairman 
John Dingell, D-Mich., of the House E nergy and 
Pow er subco m m ittee, said EPA was accep ting the p lan without p resent­ ing data show ing how and where utilities and in d ustrial p lan ts in sp ecific regions could be converted to coal fr(mi clcancrburning oil and gas without causing air quality to deteriorate. 
Studies 
Costle said each area would have to be studied as the p lan p rogresses. 
But Moffett resp onded, 
“I’m not sure it’s wise to make p olicy and d eter­ mine the feasibility af­ terwards.” 
Rep . Dave Stockm an, 
R-Mich., outlined several ex amp les of sm all com ­ p anies in his d is tric t where d ifferen t fuels were used in comp lex in­ dustrial p rocesses, say ­ ing “ I would hate to vote for any thing that would give y ou p ower to inter­ vene.” 

To Stockman. O’Leary said that the comp lex ity of the issue required that the adm inistration have as much latitude as p os­ sible, and that “ we have no intention of disturbing things badly ." 

Hig h co sts 

Rep . Philip R Sharp . 
D-lnd., said if W ashing­ ton requires utilities to convert th e ir steam p lants to coal they would simp ly p ass on ex tremely high costs to consumers. 
O’L eary said “ th a t concern is a legitim ate o n e,” but he ex p ected 
/state regulatory agencies to hold the line on rate increases. 
Rep . Tim W irth, D- 
Colo., said it may be im ­ p ossible to increase coal use if the House decision 
T hursday to relax c a r ex haust standards is sus­ tained in the Senate. 

Wasting time 

“We might be wasting tim e talking about this altogether,” said W irth, adding that C arter may have to veto w eak c a r ex haust sta n d a rd s to m ake environm ental room for increased coal combustion. 
Costle said he was dis­ ap p ointed with the House vote and would work up inform ation on the p o­ tential effect of the House action on urban air p ol­ lution. 
C arter’s coal p lan is intended to save some 3.3 million barrels of oil dai­ ly by 1985 in requiring

The San Anto nio Bar Assn. bro ug ht the suit ag ainst Gloria Alderete in co nnectio n with a fee she collected for pro mising to o btain imiiiig ra- lion papers fo r Jesus Uo racio (iau- cln.

AUSTIN 
(AP) - 
The 
Senate 
J u r is ­ p rudence Committee has withdrawn its request for an attorney g e n e ra l’s op inion on the legality of the $4 million mortgage on the State B ar’s p osh new $6 m illion Law 
Center. 
Bar p resident Gibson 
G ay le, H ouston, told com m ittee chairm an A. 
R. “ Babe” Schwartz, D- 
G alveston, in a le tte r 
Monday that the $4 m il­ lion loan from the Amer­ ican N ational Bank of 
A ustin has been “ re ­ structured.” 
“ The new note p rovides that it does not constitute a debt of the 
Stale of Tex as; that it is not a general obligation of the Slate Bar of Tex as; that it is not a charge on 
State Bar dues income; and that it is rep ay able solely out of p ledges and co ntributions to and rents and revenues from the Tex as Law C enter,” 
Gay le said. 
“ In my op inion, the note now comp lies with op inion No. 34o (in 197 4) of Atty . Gen. John Hill, as was our original in-, tent,” he said. 
Gay le said the bar is p rep ared to launch a statew ide cam p aign to raise $2.5 million to p ay off the building, but the 
Senate co m m ittee’.s p ending request for an attorney general op inion will “ p lace a cloud over and an imp ediment up on our fund-raising efforts.“ 
Op inion No. 34o said the bar could finance the building through current dues and p rivate dona­ tions. but it sp ecifically noted that the bar p re­ sident, then 
Leroy 
Jeffers, had not asked if the bar could encum ber 
— mortgage — p rop erty .

Two apartm ent pro­ jects ha\c been an­ nounced for the Paseo del 
Rio, as reported by the 
Centro 21 Task F"orcc. 
Both the Casino Build­ ing and the J’aseo del Rio 
Hotel are due to have 

 their upper floors con- 
\erted into downtown 
Iivine soace. 
River and street levels in the buildings arc being reser\ed for commercial uses. Plans for the Paseo del Rio Hotel will proba­ bly include a restaurant at river level, according to the owners. 
The projects w ill provide increased activi­ ty in the already highly developed block between 
Commerce and Crockett 
Streets.

FLACO J IMENEZ, left, performs prior to his Sunda y pa ra ­ chute jump. 

C o n ju n t o m u s ic ia n s 

 w i l l j u m p f r o m s k y 

Accordion-playing con- junlo musicians will be literally raining'*out of the sky Sunday. 
Flaco Jim e n ez and 
Mingo Saldivar, two of 
San Antonio’s leading conjunto musicians, are m aking a parachute jump to call attention to their 
Memorial 
Day 
Weekend performances. 
“ The jump will take about three minutes if the chutes open and if they don’t it will be a lot quicker,’’ Saldivar said 
Friday. 
The musicians hope to land in a field across the street from the Rockin’ 
M Club oo Hwy. 
183 between Lockhart and 
Austin. 
“ W e’re doing it to pro­ mote ourselves and our performances this week­ end.’’ Saldivar said. 
Jimenez, Saldivar and 
Augie M eyre w ill per­ form from 7 p.m. to 2 a.m . Satu rd ay at the 
Farm er’s Market. Tick­ ets are $4. 
Then if everything goes as planned, Saldivar will play at the Los Intimos 

'Sniokey’ due on holida y 

SPEC IA L T O THE E X P R E SS 
H O LLY W O O D 
- 
“ Smokey and the Ban­ dit” will be released at 
6(K) theaters on Memorial 
Day. 

Club in San Antonio Sun­ day and Jim enez w ill play at the W estern 
Palms 
Club in 
New 
Braunfels. 
To be sure the jump comes off accident free, 
Saldivar said, he and J i ­ menez have taken a basic 

 skydiving course. 
Saldivar has also had experience as an Army paratrooper during the 
195(is. However, this will be Jimenez’ first jump. 
The duo plans to make the jump at 12:3o p.m. 
Sunday.

Jim Cuitum's Happy Jazz Band^ from San Antonio, will make o special guest appearance this weekend of the intemotionally known Sacromento Jazz Festivol. The festival, which is only four i years old, drew more than 25,ooo people last yeor end is the largest of its kind in the United r a v o i i a 
States.

Hy po crisy in po licy ig no res ra m pa g e 

The Interna tio na l Co mmis­ sio n o f .Jurists ha s co ncluded tha t 
Idi 
Amin is a m a ss murderer. The co m m issio n heard testimo ny o f perso ns who hav e fled Ug anda , including two o f the Ug a nda n president’s fo rmer ca binet ministers, and they put the number o f perso ns slain in Amin's blo o dy ra mpa g e at “ mo re than 1 oo,ooo.“ 

There are repo rts o f v ictims far in ex cess o f that number but the ev idence seems certa in that 
Amin’s reg ime is cruel, reckless and ruthless and that death is an a lmo st-a uto ma tic v erdict fo r the slig htest o f rea so ns. In such a fea rso me circumsta nce, it is li­ tera lly true tha t a ll Ug a nda ns a re unsafe. 

The co mmissio n ha s no po ­ lice po wer. It ma y ha v e so me pub! ie-o p in io n po wer. 
But the repo rt is an o pen and stro ng indictment o f the United 
Na tio ns secreta ria t, the Security 
Co uncil, the General Assembly , the iro nica lly -na m ed U. N. 
Co mmissio n o n Huma n Rig hts a nd ev en indiv idua l member natio ns o f the V. X. 
They all seem to be sta nding in to ng ue-tied sho ck. 
Amin has killed the Ang lica n a rchbisho p. He* ha s killed his o wn first wife. He has killed o r caused to be killed o thers who m he co nsiders to be in his way . 

The Org anizatio n o f African 
Unity ha s ig no red the Ug a nda blo o dba th. Africa n deleg a tio ns at the U. N. pro tect Amin fro m criticism but fan the criticism o f huma n rig hts v io la tio ns in white-ruled So uthern Africa. 

The U. N. ma y well find' itself crippled by the Third 
Wo rld’s a uto ma tic ma jo rity , no w that so ma ny tribal g ro ups hav e been decla red to be so v er- ig n na tio ns. It is senseless to ex pect the U. N. to be a pro tec­ to r — ev en in principle — o f any human rig hts if it is pro tecto r o f o nly selected perso ns who a re abused. 

It is hy po crisy to deplo re in­ justice in So uthern Africa with­ o ut a pply ing the sa me kind o f po licy a nd a ctio ns to Ug a nda . 
But that is what is ha ppening o n an a ppa lling sca le. 

Fo r ex a mple, o nly Frida y the 
U. N. Security Co uncil wa s g etting pro mpt actio n fro m the 
U. S. a nd Austra lia n g o v ern­ ments. Bo th g o v ernments were taking sa nctio ns a g a inst Rho de­ sia 's info rma tio n o ffices. But no bo dy said a wo rd abo ut Ug a n­ da and we find that sickening ly stra ng e. 

And 
Brita in still ha sn't o fficially to ld Amin he ca n't a t­ tend the co mmo nwea lth co n­ ference in Lo ndo n in June.

1 97 8 mo del ca rs fo und a co m ­ pro mise in the Ho use this week.

Up fro m the g utter

— into play s, a rticles, telev isio n scripts and sundry pla ces.

 the ba sis o f la ng ua g e o r v io ­ lence, o r bo th.

We suppo se so cia l scientists wo uld find a po sitiv e no te in that. Upward mo bility , they call it! 

Sir: With regard s to R. R. Williams’ letter (May 2o), this feeble ex cu se wou ld hav e lov ed to hav e had him alon g on a moon light rid e in a B29 in 
Jan u ary of 195 3. 
While tu rn in g on to the target at 
26 ,ooo feet, ou tsid e air tem peratu re 4o d egrees below zero an d two MlGl5 s fly in g u p ou r backsid e, we m ight d iscu ss the fu tu re possibilities of d e­ fen d in g on e’s cou n try . 
This might in clu d e a possible n y lon letd own in the ex hilaratin g n ight air, or a little jog in the cou n try , or a y ear or two of rest an d relax ation as an hon ored gu est of the North Korean s. 
My tou r in Vietn am also had its list of d elightfu l possibilities. 
Howev er, to brin g him u p to d ate, 1 recom m en d he read Col. Robin son 
Risn er’s, “ The Passin g of the Night.” 
On e thin g has alway s bothered me abou t chron ic belly -achers like R. R. 
Williams. That is that if the m ilitary is su ch a fat-cat d eal, how come he’s n ot in it? They take v olu n teers, y ou kn ow. 
I su ggest that Mr. Williams get d ow n on his kn ees an d pray to God ev ery n ight for the people w ho d o, d id or hav e stood in d efen se of this cou n try . With­ ou t their d ed ication , it is u n likely that 
Mr. Williams wou ld hav e an y mon ey to pav tax es on . 
May n ard H. Kolb (Maj., USAF, ret.)

Star ran ks face red u ction s 

WASHINGTON - Ho w ma ny g enera ls do we need? 
This is a qu estion Con gress asks more in sisten tly each y ear at appro­ priation tim e an d this y ear Defen se 
S e c re ta ry H arold B row n h as an an swer he thin ks Capitol Hill will like: 
He has ord ered the arm ed serv ices to come u p by Ju ly 1 with a plan for s u b s ta n tia l re d u c tion s in the n u m bers of gen erals an d ad m irals an d h igh -ra n kin g, high-paid civ il serv an ts. 
Ra tio rises 
What d ispleases Con gress is that, ov er the y ears, the ratio of gen erals to total stren gth keeps creepin g u p. 
Tod ay , for ex am ple, the serv ices hav e 1,16 5 gen erals or ad m irals. This is on e for ev ery 1,8 oo se rv ic em en , compared to a ratio of on e per 2,6 oo at the height of the Vietn am war. 
“ 1 fin d it hard to believ e,” said 
Sen , Sam Nu n n , D-Ga., chairm an of the Sen ate Arm ed Serv ices su bcom ­ mittee on m an power, “ that it takes more gen erals to wage peace than to w age w ar.” 
Nu n n wan ts a fou r per cen t an n u al red u ction in the top ran ks ev ery y ear 

 u n til the total d rops to abou t 9oo, or on e per 2,2oo serv icemen . 
Hard to a rg ue 
On its face, Nu n n ’s proposition s are hard to argu e with, y et the factors which lie behin d the n u mbers are n ot so easy to d ispose of. 
It is easy to poin t ou t that tod ay we hav e on e fou r-star gen eral for ev ery 
5 6 ,ooo sold ie rs , c om pa re d at th e height of World War II to on e fou r- star flag for ev ery 6 oo,ooo GIs. 
Historically , howev er, what most people ov erlook is that the Un ited 
States has alway s been short on top brass. 
Sta rs unusua l 
Un til after the Civ il War, the U.S. 
Nav y d id n ’t ev en hav e on e sin gle ad ­ miral. 
U.S. G ran t, who com m an d ed the e n tire Un ion a rm y , w as on e of a han d fu l of lieu ten an t gen erals. 
There were n o fou r-star officers. 
In W orld W ar I, with ov er fou r million m en u n d er a r m s , th e U.S. 
Array had on ly three fou r-star fu ll gen erals. 
Of cou rse, in those d ay s there was n o Pen tagon an d n o top-heav y D e­ fen se D e pa rtm e n t b u r e a u c r a c y , 

Col. 
Robert D. 
Hein ! Jr. 

 w hich c a m e in to e x is te n c e w ith armed forces u n ification in 194V, be­ gin n in g of the u pward spiral in sen ior officers, becau se the n ew Defen se 
D epa rtm en t, bu ilt like a fou r-tier wed d in g cake, erected a whole series of n ew’ head qu arters an d m an age­ men t lay ers atop the serv ices. 

Deta ched 

(Tod ay , by hasty cou n t, there are some 24o gen erals an d ad m irals d e­ tached from th e ir pare n t serv ices w orkin g u n d e r the P e n ta gon on projects or agen cies for the secretary of d efen se an d his prolifery of su per­ grad e civ il serv an ts. Not on e of these gen erals m akes an y con tribu tion to the operation s or com m an d of forces within his own serv ice.) 
Y et, w hen a ppr opr ia tion tim e 

 comes, it is the serv ices, n ot the d e­ fen se secretary , who get the flak for hav in g too man y high officers. 
A n y w ay , N u n n to th e c on tra ry n otw ith s ta n d in g, th e U.S. a rm e d forces are hard ly in d an ger of gettin g like the Mex ican army . 
By comparison with represen tativ e foreign arm ed forces, the U.S. billets for .flag an d gen eral officers seem 
(an d are) qu ite mod est. 
Tod ay , we hav e 5 5 gen e rals for ev ery 1oo,ooo men on activ e d u ty . 
Do uble 
Can ad a, n orth of the bord er, more than d ou b le s th a t w ith 128 pe r 
1oo,ooo. 
B ritain ’s figu re, m ore than triple ou rs, is 18 6; Fran ce, less than Britain bu t well abov e the Un ited Stales, is 
75 , 
Socialist Swed en has a whoppin g 
373. 
Italy , howev er, Is in a class by it­ self with on e gen eral per 31o sold iers, more than 2oo Air Force gen erals for abou t 4oo airplan es, an d m ore a d ­ m irals than it has com batan t w a r­ ships in commission . 
No n u m bers cou ld be obtain ed on 
Sov iet Un ion or Warsaw Pact ratios of gen e ral to sold iers, bu t in te lli­ 

 gen ce sou rces say the Commu n ist fi­ gu res wou ld appreciably ex ceed ou rs. 
Civ il Serv ice 
L ookin g at th e Ita lia n figu re s , howev er, on e is remin d ed of the U.S. 
Civ il Serv ice an d the civ ilian sid e of ou r gov ern men t. 
With a force of ov er 2.7 million civ il serv an ts, we hire approx imately 8 ,ooo person s in GS-16 , 17 an d 18 ratin gs 
(grad es equ iv alen t: in pay an d priv i­ leges to ge n e ra ls ), toge th e r with comparable Foreign Serv ice an d Ca­ bin et an d su bcabin et jobs. 
Of these, to m an age a civ ilian po­ pu lation at the Pen tagon of 1,o31,ooo, there are 925 su pergrad es. 
What the abov e boils d own to is that the P en ta gon has n early tw ice as m an y top b ra s s c iv ilia n s (9 2 per 
1oo,ooo employ es) as it has gen erals to s old ie rs 
(5 5 pe r 
1oo,ooo serv icemen ). 
If Nu n n an d Brown a re se riou s abou t person n el econ omies at the top, they shou ld take on the Civ il S e n ice, n ot the m ilitary . Civ il Serv ice has v otes, u n ion s, captiv e com mittees in 
Con gress. All the gen erals an d a d ­ mirals hav e is a two-cen tu ry record of su fferin g pu blic in gratitu d e in si­ len ce.

Let’s liv e o r let liv e — ba n o do rs 

Sir: It seem s that all the u proar abou t smokin g has become rid icu lou s. 
As for all those who claim to be aller­ gic to tobacco smoke: How man y hav e acqu ired the allergy by imagin ation ? 
How man y hav e been certified by a d octor to be allergic to tobacco smoke? 

Recen tly I walked in to a store with an u n lit pipe in my mou th. A woman approachin g me saw m y pipe at a d is­ tan ce of 15 to 2o feet an d prom ptly began to gag. It wou ld hav e been ju st as reason able for me to gag from the possibility of her u sin g a perfu m e or somethin g scen ted . 

If we are goin g to go to ex tremes, why n ot ban people wearin g scen ts, or those who hav e bod y od or, from pu blic places. Some scen ts an d bod y od or are u s offen siv e to some as tobacco smoke is to others. Some folks are so d eod or­ ized their presen ce d eod orizes large rooms. Some giv e the impression they hav e been han d lin g old billy goats. 
Each probably offen d s the other. P e r­ haps it’s tim e to thin k of the old philosophy of liv e an d let liv e. 
W. McCraken 

Yo ung is do ing wha t he plea ses 

WASHINGTON — Andrew 
'Yo ung , the U.S. a mba ssa do r to the 
United 
Na tio ns, ha s emerg ed a s the mo st talka tiv e and co ntro v ersia l member o f 
President Ca rter’s tea m. 
He is also the most aggressiv e an d con sisten t. 
Seld om a d ay goes by that he d oesn 't make the head lin es with some v iv id criticism of some cou n try , in clu d in g his own , abou t how they a re bein g beastly to his fellow blacks. 
R ecen tly , he has been w an d erin g arou n d Africa lectu rin g Ian Smith ot 
Rhod esia an d P rim e M in ister John 
Vorster of Sou th Africa on the sin s of white min ority ru le. 
P a ssin g throu gh Lon d on , he con ­ d em n s the old B ritish colon ial a s ­ su mption s, an d comin g back, he su g­ gests that the Swed es are liberal bu t are abou t as liberal with the blacks as the whites are in the Qu een s borou gh of New York — thereby in fu riatin g the political lead ers in both Swed en an d 
Qu een s. 
No immunity 

Nobod y is im m u n e to An d y You n g’s criticism, n ot ev en the Carter ad m in ­ istration . 
When he cam e back throu gh Lon d on from Africa an d was asked what he thou ght ab ou t the C u b an s s e n d in g 
“ m ilitary ad v isers” to Ethiopia, he said that the State D epartm en t had d en ou n ced this in terv en tion . 
He su pposed , he said iron ically , that he ou ght to d o the sam e, bu t m ay be 
Cu ba’s in terv en tion cou ld be a good thin g — might ev en sav e some liv es. 
When Presid en t Carter was asked at his latest press con feren ce why he fired Maj. Gen . Sin glau b for speakin g ou t again st the withd rawal of Am eri­ can grou n d troops in Sou th Korea bu t tolerated An d y You n g’s d issen ts from official policy , “ Well, I kn ow of n o in stan ce when An d y You n g has v iolat­ ed the policy d escribed .” 
What he plea ses 
The tru th is that An d y You n g is d o­ in g what he pleases; he is goin g bey on d , ev en d efy in g C arter’s spirit of compromise. He is irritatin g the allies while Carter is try in g to win their co­ operation . He is in fu riatin g Con gress precisely when Carter is try in g to work alu t some kin d of con sen su s at home 
,an d abroad . 
He is ev en pickin g fights with the 
Swed es, of all people, by su ggestin g that they are “ terrible rac ists,” an d while Jim m y Carter keeps su pportin g him, his State Departm en t is appalled by You n g’s an tics, an d m em bers of the 
Cabin et won d er what the Presid en t wou ld thin k if they popped off all ov er the world like An d y You n g. 
In short, the main criticism here is n ot of You n g bu t of Carter. The Presi­ d en t kn ows You n g v ery well — better than an y bod y else in Washin gton . 
You n g wan ted this job at the Un ited 
Nation s more than an y other — an d as the m ost a r tic u la te an d a ttr a c tiv e black in C a rte r’s presid e n tial c a m ­ paign , he got it. 
Wro ng ro le 
Bu t You n g is n ot actin g like a U.S. am bassad or to the Un ited Nation s. 
He is actin g like an am bassad or of the Un ited States to Africa, an d ev en like an am bassad or of Black Africa to 
Washin gton . 
You can talk to him at len gth abou t his job, bu t he seld om men tion s this cou n try ’s problems with Can ad a, Latin 
A m erica, E u rope , A sia, the Sov iet 
Un ion , Chin a, or Japan . 
As a Sou thern politician , he u sed to complain with great eloqu en ce that the 
North cou ld on ly thin k “ w hite,” bu t n ow he on iy seems to thin k “ black.” 
An d y You n g is n ot the first prom in ­ en t poiitieian who has held this job as 
U.S. am b a ssa d or to the Un ited N a ­ tion s. 
Eisen hower n omin ated Hen ry Cabot 
Lod ge for the job. Ken n ed y sen t Ad lai 
S tev en son th e re to get rid of him . 
John son d iv e rte d A rth u r G old b erg from the S u pre m e C ou rt, an d P a t 
Moy n ihan was the first am abassad or again st rather than to the Un ited Na­ tion s. Bu t An d y You n g is som ethin g qu ite d ifferen t. 
Pla tfo rm 
He is u sin g the Un ited Nation s as a platform for his own v iews of the racial con flicts of the world , an d more than all the other U.S. am bassad ors in that job, he has a powerfu l political con sti­ tu en cy su pportin g him. 
Carter cou ld fire an y other m em ber of his Cabin et withou t losin g an y major bod y of v oters, bu t Y ou n g has the blacks on his sid e, an d seems to thin k he can d o an d say what he pleases. 
If he were a con gressm an , or a co­ lu m n ist, or a propagan d ist, n obod y cou ld object to the ard en t v iolen ce of his thou ght — ev en if he were an as­ sistan t to the Presid en t, argu in g his rac ial philosoph y — bu t as an am b a ssa d or to the U n ited N ation s, fly in g arou n d th e w orld le c tu rin g ev ery bod y on their moral d u ties — this is somethin g n ew in the history of po­ lities an d d iplomacy . 
An d the respon sibility for this is n ot 
An d y You n g’s bu t the Presid en t’s. 
You n g m ad e clear to the Presid en t from the start what he in ten d ed to d o, an d lie has d on e it. 
He’s n ot an am bassad or, or ev en a faithfu l re porter of Jim m y C a rte r’s hu man rights policies, bu t a brillian t propagan d ist an d ev en a prov ocateu r for his own v iews of the racial con flict.

NEW YORK TIMES SERVICE 

WASHINGTON — Th e Carter arn in - istratio n , wh ich is d raftin g a n ew im m igratio n p o licy fo r th e n atio n , rep o rted ly is h av in g seco n d th o u gh ts abo u t a p ro p o sal th at wo u ld gran t so me fo rm o f am n esty to man y o f th e estimated to tal o f six to eigh t millio n illegal alien s n o w in th e co u n try . 
Alth o u gh th ey stre s se d th a t th e m atter is still bein g d ebated an d d is­ cu ssed . an d th at th e p ro p o sal itself h as no t been aban d o n ed , sev eral Go v ern ­ men t so u rces rep o rt serio u s q u estio n s abo u t th e p lan were raised Tu esd ay at a meetin g with Presid en t Carter, an d th at th e meetin g en d ed with th e issu e far fro m reso lv ed . 
Mo re sp ecifically , th ey said th at sev eral p erso n s at th e sessio n , wh ich was atten d ed by abo u t 3o ran kin g 
Cabin et an d ad min istratio n o fficials, co mp lain ed th at no blan ket amn esty sh o u ld be mad e u n til better estimates are o btain ed o f ju st h o w man y p erso n s it wo u ld in v o lv e an d wh at so rt o f bu rd en s it wo u ld p lace o n o th er go ­ v ern men t agen cies. 
“ Th ere was so me co n cern abo u t th e so rt o f d rain th is co u ld p u t o n Go v ern ­ men t serv ices, su ch as u n emp lo y men t 

"So me o f the a g encies tha t ha ve to p ro d uce services think it's sca ry to g ra n t a mnesty witho ut k no wing fo r sure wha t the imp a ct will b e'

An o th er co n cern rep o rted ly raised at th e m e e tin g was w h eth e r am n esty sh o u ld be gran ted in su ch a way th at it wo u ld simp ly p ro tect p erso n s alp ead v h ere again st d ep o rtatio n , o r wh eth er it sh o u ld be d o n e in a way th at wo u ld giv e th em tin* righ t to p etitio n to h av e sp o u ses, ch ild ren an d o th er relativ es en ter th e co u n try . 
“ It's a d ifficu lt p ro blem, may be an u n m an agable o n e,” said o n e p erso n wh o atten d ed th e meetin g. “ Bu t it’s safe to say th at we’re still wo rkin g at it, an d try in g righ t no w to h am m er it o u t."

Miss B ry an t cam e by h er religio n n atu rally . Sh e was bo rn 37 y ears ago in a p reach er’s bed .

Barn sd all, Okla., wh en sh e wen t in to labo r, an d th e baby was bo rn in th e bed o f h er u n cle, th e Rev . Lu th er Berry . 
Sh e ap p eared d ead , an d th e d o cto r rev iv ed h er with altern ate d rau gh ts o f co ffee an d w h iskey . T o d ay , M iss 
Bry an t is so stro n gly o p p o sed to d rin k th at sh e refu se s n igh tc lu b e n ga ge ­ men ts. 
Gran d p a was a refin ery wo rker, u n ­ til h is ey es were seared by an ex p lo d ­ in g jet o f h o t tar. 
He tu rn ed to religio n wh ile ly in g in th e h o sp ital. Th ereafter, h e’d wan d er blin d ly ab o u t to w n , a p p ro a c h in g stran gers, an d d em an d in g “ Are y o u sav ed ?” 
Dad was an o ilfield ro u stabo u t, an d s o m e tim e s th e B ry a n ts liv ed in a trailer with n o th in g bu t th e wo o d s fo r a p riv y . Bu t th ey h ad religio n . 
Sunda y scho o l

B ible fo r a r gu m e n ts in h er figh t again st h o mo sex u al righ ts — a fact th at is o ften lo st o n th e p u blic, becau se w h en sh e begin s ex p o u n d in g Scrip tu re th e TV in terv iewers cu t h er sh o rt an d th e rep o rters sto p takin g n o tes. 

An o th er iro n y in th e Miami issu e is th at th e wo man wh o sp o n so red th e h o ­ m o sex u al righ ts o rd in an ce is R u th 
Sh ack, th e wife o f Miss B ry an t’s agen t. 
An ita en d o rsed h er can d id acy , an d co n tribu ted $1,(1oo to h er camp aign . 
Sh e an d Miss Bry an t are as far ap art religio u sly as th ey a re p o litically . 
Wh ile Miss Bry an t was gro win g u p in a fu n d am e n talist B ap tist h o m e, M rs. 
Sh ack was bein g raised in a liberal 
Jewish h o me in New Yo rk. Her fath er was a fo u n d er o f th e Refo rm Tem p le o n Lo n g Islan d . 
Sh e rem em bers v iv id ly bein g 11 o r 
12 y ears o ld d u rin g Wo rld W ar II an d beco min g aware fo r th e first time th at millio n s o f Jew s were bein g m u rd ered in German y . 
“ Th ey were killed becau se th ey were u n p o p u lar,” say s Mrs. Sh ack, “ an d 1 rem em ber fearin g fo r my o wn life." 
Mrs. Sh ack h ad wo rked fo r sev eral liberal cau ses in Miami, bu t n ev er h eld p o litical o ffice befo re h er electio n in 
Sep tem ber to th e M etro p o litan Dad e 
Co u n ty Co mmissio n . Miami is ru n by th is metro p o litan fo rm o f go v ern men t. 
Befo re th e electio n , can d id ates fo r th e co m m issio n w ere in v ited by th e 
Dad e Co u n ty Co alitio n fo r th e H u m an ­ istic Righ ts o f Gay s to meet al a YMCA to h ear abo u t d iscrimin atio n . 
Mrs. Sh ack was o n e o f th o se wh o atten d ed , was en d o rsed by th e h o mo ­ sex u als, an d wo n th eir electio n . 
Ga y rig hts 
On e o f h er first acts as c o m m is ­ sio n er was to in tro d u ce a h o mo sex u al righ ts am en d men t to th e co u n ty ’s civ il righ ts o rd in an ce. It giv es th em p ro ­ tectio n fro m d iscrimin atio n in areas o f em p lo y m en t, h o u sin g an d p u blic ac ­ co mmo d atio n . 
Sh e sees Dad e Co u n ty ’s h o mo sex u al co mmu n ity as an o th er gro u p o f p eo p le bein g d en ied p ro tectio n o f th e law so ­ lely becau se th ey are u n p o p u lar. 
“ It is n o t illegal to be a h o mo sex u al in th e state o f Flo rid a,” sh e say s, “ an d we can n o t d en y th em civ il righ ts if th ey are in d eed law-abid in g, tax -p ay ­ in g m em bers o f th e co m m u n ity .” 
Miss Bry an t go t o n th e telep h o n e to 

Mrs. Sh ack an d tried to ch an ge h er p o sitio n , q u o tin g fro m Lev iticu s an d o th er sectio n s o f th e Bible. 
“ 1 p o in ted o u t th at 1 am a legislato r, n o t a th eo lo gian ," say s Mrs. Sh ack, 
"an d th at sin ce it is n o t illegal to be a h o mo sex u al, th ere is n o basis fo r h er argu m en ts.” 
Bu t Miss Bry an t fo u n d th e p ro p o sed amen d men t in to lerable. "It h its at th e v ery h eart o f Ch ristian ity ,” sh e say s. 
“ It’s like fo rcin g p o rk d o wn th e th ro at o f a Jew .” 
A h earin g o n th e am en d m en t was h eld last Jan u ary 18. Miss Bry an t d e­ cid ed to atten d , bu t was an x io u s abo u t an e n t e r ta i n e r m a kin g a p o litical statemen t. 
“ 1 h ad alway s av o id ed co n tro v ersial th in gs,” sh e say s. “ 1 was afraid . I’d walk th ro u gh th e h o u se, cry in g. Th en 
I’d th in k: ‘If Go d is fo r me, h o w can an y bo d y be again st m e?’ Th ere was a d iv in e d istu rban ce with in m e."

« IFK’s last call may hav e been to Garner 
Gamer lives in Uva ld e memo ries 

The last telephone call J ohn 
F. Kennedy made may hav e been to Uv alde. 
J ohn Nance Garner was 9 5 y ears old that day — Nov . 22 
19B3. 
¡’resident KenntMly called the former v K-e president to wish him a happy birthday . 
Tht're is reason to believ e the call was made from the presidential plane in which President and Mrs. Kennedy and Gov . and Mrs. fonnally were fly ­ ing from Fort Worth to Lov e Field in 
Dallas. 
On their arriv al at Lov e H eld, the 
Kennedy 's and the Connally s got in the presidential automobile — its bubble top of bullet-proof glass unused — and headed a motorcade through cheering 
Dallas crowds. 
President Kennedy was shot at 12:3o p.m. 
The call to Garner cam e “ about two hours before w e heard the terrib le 

Whe n Pre s ide nt John F. Ke nne dy c a lle d John Ga rne r Nov . 72, 1 9 63 . to w^ish him a ha ppy 9 5 th birthda y , 
Mrs . M a ry Sa la za r a ns we re d the te le phone . 
M rs . 
S a la za r wa s 
Ga rne r's de v ote d hous e k e e pe r- a tte nda nt during his fina l y e a rs . 

 news that the P resid en t had been shot.” 
The story of the telephone call is well known in Uv alde. But the ev ents of that day and those that followed were so ov erw helming if the call to Garner was publicized ov er the nation, it was lost. 
Bonnie and I were told of the Ken­ nedy telep h on e c all to G arner in 
Uv alde last weekend. 
We went there to do this story on some little-known episodes in Garner’s long career. And we wanted to tell of the ex ceptionally interesting Garner 
Museum. 
We got the idea for the Garn(*r story from an in trig u in g colum n in the 
Uv alde Leader-News sev eral months ago. The column was written by Pub­ lisher Harry Hornby J r., a close friend of Garner in Garner’s later y ears. 
Cal Newton, ex ecutiv e v ice president of the Uv alde Chamber of Commerce, arranged a number of interv iews for us. 
One was with Mrs. J ewel Kincaid, a neighbor and c lo se friend of the 
Garners, who, at the family ’s request, screened Garner’s interv iews during his last y ears. 

Ga rne r's 9 o th birthda y pa rty — a nd a good time wa s ha d by a ll!

Garner called her “ Cap’n.” 
“ Harry Hornby headed that big 9 oth birthday party for Mr. Garner,” Mrs. 

Kincaid said. “ But after that the cus­ tom was for Uv alde people to gather in his front y ard on his birthday . Garner would come out and talk with them. 
“ On that 9 3th birthday , the house- keeper-nurse cam e out to the gather­ ing to tell Mr. Garner he was wanted on the telephone. 
“ I walked with him up the steps but did not go inside. As he cam e out he said: 
“ ’That w as the P resid en t of the 
United S tates w ish ing m e a happy birthday .’” 
Newton had also giv en us the name of M rs. M ary S alazar, the house- keeper-nurse who had been Garner's aftendant during the last y ears. The late Tully Garner, the v ice president’s son. had arranged for her to do so. 
Mrs. Kincaid called Mrs. Salazar for us. 

Our interv iew with Mrs. Sala'/ar. alone in the quiet liv ing room of her m other’s home, was one of the most mov ing we hav e ev er had, 
“ That m orning when Mr. Garner went out in the y ard for his birthday p arty ,’’ Mrs. Salazar said , “ I w as alone in the house. The telephone rang and I answt'red it. 
“ ’This is J ohn F. Kennedy . I want to wish Mr. Garner a happy birthday .’ 
“ The President then said he was on his way from Fort Worth to Dallas. 
“ I told the P re sid en t that Mr. 
Garner was at his birthday party , that 
I would go out and tell him who was callin g and that 1 thought he would come,

“ I w ent out and told him and he came inside. I closed the door behind

THEY GAVE THEIR LIVES 

TO PRESERVE YOUR FREEDOM 

We are inclined to take for granted the many forms of freedom which we enjoy in this country, perhaps because we have never been forced to live without them; and yet we must remind ourselves of the sacrifices that have been made in order to preserve them for us. by those who were called upon to give their lives in battle. Not only on Memorial Day but throughout the year we should honor those brave heroes, and give our thanks to God for this wonderful free nation we have because of them. And since the list of our freedoms includes the right to worship God as we choose, the Church of your choice IS the best place to express your gratitude. 

A Spe€ial 
Invitation 
To Attend 
Church From

Products Co.

Methodist conference to consecrate deacons 

Volunteer worker at the chapel of the San Antonio State Hospital# 
Helen Holloway# left# greeted the Rev. Fred Scheffel# center# along with chaplain Jenaro Fernandez. The Rev. Mr. Scheffel was among a group of visiting southeast area ministers who recently visited the 
State Hospital chapel's open house. 

Diaconal ministers will be consecrated for the first time during the 
Southwest Texas Annual 
Conference meeting 
Monday through Thurs­ day at Travis Park 
United 
Methodist 
Church. 
Bishop J. Chess Lo- vern, resident bishop of the San Antonio area, will preside over the conference when he con­ venes the 119th session at 
1 p.m. Monday. 
The consecration of both lay men and lay wo­ men into a professional 

 si' 

 a m 
> m y n i a H 
J C i w w 9 

“ Iby a potluck dinner, 

 i 
The 7 p.m. service will lie ironducted by the Rev. 
Glenn Akridge of Mobile. 
Ala. career of diaconal min­ istry in the United Meth­ odist Church was made possible by action of the 
1978 General Conference of the United Methodist 
Church. 
“ This annual confer­ ence will consecrate two persons into this new lay ministry of our church,” 
Bishop Lovern said. 
Another 12 persons will be recognized as diaconal 
Gospel challenges lifestyle 

Few subjects are a" emotionally explosive as human sexuality. Few areas of that subject are as controversial as ho­ mosexuality. 
Few Americans com­ bine the qualities of ta­ lent, beauty, strung opin­ ions and crusading dis-' position as dynamically as does Anita Bryant. 
Mixing those ingredients with an election vote in 
Miami, Ha., about a so- called civil rights ordin­ ance has created an ex­ plosion felt all over the nation. 
The atmosphere is wrong for a rational ana­ lysis of the issue of ho­ mosexuality and dis­ crimination. 
A sensa­ tion hungry media seizes oach occasion lo titillate. 
Homosexual advocates have been searching for a cause celebre around uhich to rally. 
Parents are deeply concerned about their own rights to transmit to their children insights about religious values and sexuality in an in­ creasingly permissive society. 
Rains eyed over state 

Heavy thunderstorms that hit West Texas in the past three days ended — for a while — Friday morning, but kicked up again late in the day. 
The rest of the state was under clear to partly cloudy skies and warm temperatures. 
On Thursday night the heavy thunderstorms dumped as much as two inches of rain over parts of Northwest Texas and the western portion off the Red River Valley. 
Shamrock, 1oo miles east of Amarillo, reported 3.14 inches. 
Fog and haze lingered over Northeast Texas reducing visibility to ar­ ound three miles early in the day. Winds across the state were southerly at five to 1o miles per hour. 
Temperatures early in the afternoon ranged from 77 at Del Rio and El 
Paso to 88 at TVIer and 91 at Midland. 
The National Weather 
Services said warm tem­ peratures with scattered showers would continue through Saturday.
