 lim m y g T 

First 

As difficult as rational analysis may be, it is necessary for thoughtful citizens to examine the issue carefully. 
Perspective 
Perspective deter­ mines one’s perception. ll one’s perspective is a 
Biblical viewpoint on authority, the plain leaching of the scripture is that homosexual beha- 
\ ior is disordered beha­ vior. 
Despite attempts by some churchmen to redefine terms or reject sections of the scripture as colored by the writers’ ideas rather than the in­ spiration of God, the 

 scripture shows that God created human beings as heterosexual beings and gave them the gift of sexuality both for their fulfillment and procrea­ tion. 
The problem is created for the person with a commitment to Biblical authority as to how per­ sons involved in disor­ dered behavior and out of harmony with God's re­ vealed intention for them are to be treated. 
(’hnstian love de­ mands that they- be ac­ cepted as persons and assisted in every way possible toward whole­ ness. 
The problem is com­ pounded by the mistaken notion by some homosex­ ual advocates that ac­ cepting one as a person also demands approval of behavior. Not so. 
It is possible to have the grace to accept one’s worth and to love gen­ uinely a person wiiile re­ jecting totally his li­ festyle. Jesus demon­ strated that over and again. 
The isvsue then emerges 

 as to what if any limita­ tions should be placed on advocates of a disordered lifestyle. 
Do parents, for in­ stance, have a right to reject the idea of a per­ son committed to homo­ sexual lifestyle becoming an authority figure ami model of behavior as a public school teacher? 
Is the current outcry for rights for homosex­ uals the same kind of just cause espoused in the 
196o’s in agitating for re­ jection of racial 
(Jiscrimination? 
In a society of plura­ lism. most people of Bib­ lical commitment as 
Christians and Jews re­ frain from demanding that their perspective be honored as socially healthier for the whole community? 
The 
(juestions are complex. Slogans and rallies on either side usually fai! to deal ade­ quately v^ilh them. How­ ever, some principles need to be applied. 
Homosexual militants cannot justify their movement in the noble

 terms of the racial jus­ tice movement because it fails the test of unix ersa- lit.v. 
The test of universality asks the crucial question of what would happen if every person were to fol­ low a particular princi­ ple. Society obviously would be hurt or des­ troyed rather than helped and strengthened if every person were to become homosexual. 
Basic rights 
On the other hand, persons disordered or not have the right to be. 
Their basic human rights remain and should be re­ spected. The Constitution calls it the right to “ life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness.” 
Parents and citizens at large have rights also. 
Teaching school is ac­ tually a privilege, not a basic right. 
The privilege of being trusttMl with leadership is forfeited »when one chooses to live a lifestyle out of harmony with the highest good of a com­ munity. 
A majority of citizens have the right to deter­ mine the boundaries with which they regulate their community affairs. 
Th('y have a right to try to create the best atmos­ phere for their value systems lo be transmit­ ted to their young. Social legislation has always lieen justified on the be­ half of the young and the weak. 
Similar 
The first century world into which the gospel of 
.lesus 
Christ was launched was similar to our day. 
Homosexuality was a popular and socially ap­ proved lifestyle. The claims of the gospel challenged their li­ festyle. 
The basic struggle was in individual lives find­ ing strength and direc­ tion toward wholeness. 
This issue will have to be 
V oted on by the citizens of 
Miami and other com- munilies. 
Votes will not deter­ mine solutions, however. 
Those solutions come through jiKjividuals

“ Old-Fashioned Day” 
Sunday at the church.

NEW YORK (A P ) — 
Patriarch Elias IV of 
Antioch, where the an­ cient followers of Jesus first were called “ Chrls- tiaiLs” in ridicule by the predominantly pagan population, says they’re now well regarded there. 
’’The Christians of An­ tioch today are very highly respected,” says the head of one of the most ancient jurisdic­ tions of church history, niM' involving about 3.5 million believers in several 
Moslem-ruled countries. 
“ We consider our­ selves an integral part of the Arab word, and are free in our thinking and in our worship.” he told a news conference.

Harry Hornby Jr., editor and publisher of the Uvalde Leoder-News, was a close friend of John Garner in Garner's later years. 
When Garner died, Hornby devoted page after page of his newspaper to stories and pictures on rtie life of the former vice president. Garner came to Uvalde in 1893, when he was 24 and supposedly threatened by deoth with tubercubsis. He died 
Nov. 7, 1967, ¡ust 15 days short of his 99th birthday. 

Here’s Garner — to p hat awkwardly back o n his head — and Mrs. Garner o n their way to dinner with the king and queen o f England — then two lo ng tables o f guests at o ne o f the dinners the Garners gav e each y ear fo r Presi­ dent Ro Ov Sev elt — a great picture o f 
Garner and his friend. Will Ro gers, at a So uth Tex as barbecue. 
The wall filled with gav els is a sto ry in itself. Here are a few: 
A gav el made fro m a rail split by 
Go v . Jim Ho gg — o ne fro m a timber put in the White Ho use ro o f after the 
British burned it in 18 15 — o ne fro m a po plar tree under which Ro bert E. Lee said farewell to his tro o ps — o ne fro m wo o d fro m the ship o n which Oliv er 
Hazard Perry fo ught the British o n 

Lake Erie (“ We hav e met the enemy and they are o urs” ) — o ne with the head fro m an elm under which Sam 
Ho usto n signed a treaty with the In­ dians and the handle fro m a Garner pecan tree — o ne fro m wo o d fro m a staircase in the o ld Co llingswo rth 
Co unty Co urtho use carry ing bullet ho les fro m a cattleman-nester gun battle. . . 
I canno t end th is sto ry witho ut telling when I saw Gamer. 
When I was a Memphis newspaper­ man in my early 2os I was sent to Wa­ shingto n o n a sto ry . It was my first time to go to Washingto n and I was so impressed that I bo ught a pair o f spats and bo rro wed a derby hat. 
A newspaperm an to o k me to a 

Garner press co nference in the Capito l. 
It was just befo re o r just after the 19 3 2 electio n. 
A real furo r was under way . The 
Depressio n was at its wo rst — banks were clo sing and Ro o sev elt had just said there wasn’t a bank in the United 
States in which mo ney was safe. Ho w edito rs, pundits and o ppo sing po liti­ cians to re into him as irrespo nsible. 
As we cro wded into Garner’s o ffice 
— there sto o d a rugged little man. Yo u nev er fo rgo t his sandy -white ey ebro ws. 
A repo rter quickly asked: 
“ Mr. Speaker, what abo ut Ro o se­ v elt’s charge abo ut the banks? ” 
Garner nev er paused: 
“ Well, it’s the truth, ain’t it? ” 
And that was that. 
Mrs. Garner o utstanding, also 

No sto ry o n Jo hn Garner is co mplete witho ut the sto ry o f his wife, Ettie Rheiner Garner. 

They were married in 18 9 .i. When Garner went to Co ngress in 19 tl3 , Mrs. Garner became his secretary . She filled this po st 3 o y ears. 

To day , when keeping a co ngressman and his staff co sts mo re than $1 millio n a y ear, life o f a co ngressman in tho se early y ears is incredible. 

“ Mrs. Garner and I liv ed in a bo arding ho use," Garner o nce said in an interv iew. 
“ There was no o ffice building fo r co ngressmen. 
1 had to make my o ffice al the bo arding ho use and was allo wed no mo ney fo r o ffice rental. 

“ I ro de a streetcar the mile o r mo re to and fro m the Capito l. 

“ I go t $5.<111o in salary and a secretarial al­ lo wance o f $1,2oo a y ear. My wife was my se­ cretary and run my o ffice.” 

Mrs. tiaro er was no ted fo r the effectiv e way she ran the Garner o ffice, but there was ano ther side to Mrs. Garner. She was a fine artist. 

The museum has a number o f first-class paintings by her. Her hand-painted china is beautiful and her needlewo rk o utstanding.

OPEN MEMORIAL DAY 

ASSOCIATED ERESS 
(■HICAGO — Home runs by 
Manny Trillo and Bobby Mureer backed the sharp pitching of Bill 
Bonham Friday and powered the Chicago Cubs to a 4-2 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates. 

The triumph was the 19th in *24 games for the t'ubs who moved within ono-half game of the first place F’irates ill the National League Fust. 

Trillo’s homer, his fourth, capped a iwo-run fourth inning. Murcer hit his seventh of the season in the sixth to break a 2-2 tie and band ,Iohn (Cande­ laria, H-1. his first loss of the year. 
Pittsburgh look a 1-o lead in the se­ cond on singles by Al Oliver, Rennie 
Stennett and Phil Garner. 
Ca g e tip s 

The first session of the 
St. M ary’s University basketball camp for boys ages 8-14 will begin June 
o at the school’s Alumni 
Gym. 
Instructors at the camp will include St. Mary’s 
Head (’oach Fd Mess- barg(‘r; Earl Meyer, head coach of Burbank; and 
,Iim Alferi, head coach at 
.Antonian. 
The first session, one of five, will go until June 1o. 
The other sessions for the boys will be held June l:i-17, June 2o-24 and 
June ’iT-July 1. The ses­ sion for girls will be July 
4-8. 
Camp sessions will be conducted 
Monday through Friday from 9.3o a.m. until 4 p.m. 

J o h n so n la u d ed 

, Brent Johnson, an all- district football and baseball player at Jef- fetson, received an ap­ pointment to the U.S. 
M ilitary Academy al 
West Point, N.V., it was announced Friday. 

S o e e e r cliiiie 
A beginners soeeer clinic for women 18 and over will be held at 1o a.m. Saturday al the o1- mos Basin Sports Com­ plex. 
Another soccer clinic for persons interested in refereeing is scheduled for noon near the Coca- 
Cola Bottling Co.. 162 
Exposition.

Ya nk s ro ll o n 

ASSOCIATED PRESS 
NEW YORK - Reggie Jack­ son’s lowering home run touched off a five-run rally and 
Mickey Rivers ripped four sin gles as the New York Yankees downed the Chicago White Sox 
8-6 Friday night. 

Thurman Munson drove in three runs with a double, triple and sacrifice fly as the Yankees overcame an early fiverun deficit. 
The White Sox had knocked out New 
York starter Catfish Hunter in the se­ cond inning and built a 5-(l lead on a two-run homer by Oscar Gamble, a 
Ivvo-run single by Jim Essian and a sacrifice fly by Richie Zisk, who later tagged his 13th homer of the season. 
But Jackson’s seeond-inning blast halfway up in the right field bleachers, some 45o feet away, touched off the 
Yankee comeback. Rivers singled in another run aind Munson’s triple drove in two more, knocking out Chi­ cago starter Ken Brett. The first of three Chambliss hits, a single, tied the score. 
Two innings later, Chambliss dropped a pop fly double to left and scored on Jackson’s single. Then New 
York added two wrap-up runs in the sixth on Munson’s sacrifice fly and 
Chambliss’ third hit.

Tig ers spo il 
Bird debut 

DETROIT (A P) — Second baseman Tito Fuentes’ error in the sixth inning let in the winning run as the Seattle Mariners edged the Detroit Tigers 21 Friday night and spoiled the season pitching debut of Mark “ The Bird” Fidyrch. 
Sena to r sup p o rts 
TV g rid 

O r io le s, 6 -o 

Dan Meyer hit a two-out double in the inning. Then Stein’s routine grounder bounced off Fuentes’ glove, allowing Meyer to score. 
Another poor fielding play led to the first Seattle run in the fifth. Bob Stin­ son singled and Larry Milbourne hit a one-out fly ball to center. Ron LeFlore appeared to catch the ball over his shoulder, but he dropped it and it was ruled a double. Then Dave Collins hit a sacrifice fly. 
Fidrych, the American League’s 
1976 Rookie of the Year, came off the injured list Tuesday after undergoing knee surgery in March. A crowd of 
44,2o7 jammed Tiger Stadium to watch the Bird, who gave up eight hits.

B re w e rs, 6 -5 

M ILW A U K EE (A P) - Steve Brye’s sacrifice fly in the bottom of the ninth inning scored Sal Bando. lifting the 
Milwaukee Brewers to a 6 -5 victory over the Texas Rangers Friday night. 
Bando singled with one out in the ninth and raced to third on Cecil 
Cooper’s single off Paul Lindblad, 1-.‘L setting up Brye’s third game-winning 
RBI of the season. 
Jim Fregosi’s sacrifice fly tied the game for Texas at 5 -5 in the ninth after the Hangers had filled the bases with none out.

(Her- 

M INNEAPOLIS (AP) — Sen. 
Wendell Anderson, D-Minn, in­ troduced a resolution Friday urging the National Football 
League to keep its playoff and championship games on tele­ vision. 

Ill a statement released by his Min­ neapolis office, Anderson said he was deeply concerned by reports that pro­ moter B ill Sargent had offered the league $4oo million for exclusive rights to playoff and championship games over the next five years. 
The games then would be televised in theaters via closed circuit, with fans paying admission to see them. 
If the N FL agrees, Anderson said.^ 
“ this system would deny tens of mil­ lions of Americans the opportunity to watch televised football games in their homes.” 
The senator noted that two of every five Americans watched the 1976 Super 
Bowl on television. 
“ Most of them would be unable to attend such games even if enough tickets were available, and few could afford the extremely high price of a ticket to view championship games in private theaters,” Anderson said. 
Po rker to ug h 

CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex. (A P ) - 
David Thornally of Arkansas-Little 
Rock sank a 55-foot birdie putt on the first hole of a sudden death playoff 
Friday to capture the medalist title at the NCA.A Division II golf tournament. 
Thornally, who led the first two days of the 72-hole tournament, defeated third round leader Cleve Uoldwater of 
Troy State, Ala., whose Trojan team­ mates captured their second straight team title with an 1168 aggregate score. 
Brisk winds kept scores high for the final round. Thornally shot a 75 in regulation piay over the 6,71o-yard 
Padre Isles Country Club course, while 
Coldwater finished with a 76, birdieing the IBth-hole to force the playoff. 
F rid a y ’s best score was a one- under-par 7o by Troy State’s Ronny 
Mobley, propelling him into third place in the individual standings. 
Edinboro, Pa., State’s Jay Spitale was fourth. 
Defending champion Mike Nicolelte of Rollins, Fla., College, was one stroke off the pace going into Friday’s round, but he skied to an 83 and finished well out of the running.

4o bo uts. The a ctio n co ntinues Sa turda y a nd Sunda y nig hts, with bo uts sta rting a t 7 p.m. ea ch nig ht.

Gua rd sig ns 

All-city guard Freddy Medina of 
Lanier, and TCIL AAA star Willie 
Hodges of St. Gerard’s have signed with St. Mary’s. 
Medina, 5-8, averaged 15.4 points per game this past season for the Voks, while the 6-2 Hodges had a 16.8 average for the Royals. Both players will be participating on the South team, coacli by Rattler mentor Ed Messbarger, in the local North-.South all-star game 
.lune 3 at Sams Center Gym. 

HOLE-IN-ONE 
Carl Jark and R.D. Huff both aced the 15o-yard fifth hole at Sam Houston golf course Friday afternoon. Jark used a five-iron to score his hole-in-one and Huff selected a six-iron to record his ace.

Son Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS— Soturdgy Moy 28 1977 
H Poge 
3< 

By JOHN HINKS 
OF THE EXPRESS NEWS STAFF 
The 1977 San Antonio city championship and a regional finals berth in the state playoffs will be at stake when the Marshall Rams and Roosevelt Rough Riders clash at 8 p.m. Saturday at Insel* mann Field. 

HINKS 

The winner will meet the Victoria 
Stroman-Vorpus C'hristi t’arroH victor next week in the Cla.ss AAAA-Regioti 
IV finals tor one of the tour berths in tile state tournament. 
Stroman. holding a one-game lead in that series, invades Corpus 
C h risti’s 
Cabaniss 
Field for a 4 p.m. game 
Saturday. 
Another game will follow if Carroll wins. 
W hile Roosexelt’s starting pitching choice is an uncer­ tainty between ('arl 
Siiear (11-4) or Cordy 
(b'st'll (2-1), Marsliall should be in good shape in that department. 
Th(‘ Rams uill be rehing once more on their ace, Roddy Wiliis, who will t(ite an 11-1 mark to the mound tonight with three days' rest. 
22 straight 

Willis is working on a string of 22 straight scoreless innings and in the playoffs has allowed only three hits in 
19 innings, with 25 strikeouts and 11 walks. Only a sixth-inning leadoff bunt by Roosevelt’s Joe Moon kept him from a no-hitter in last Tuesday’s 5-9 opener. 
“ With him pitching, they (Hoose- 
\elt) will probably be bunting a lot,” 
Marshall center fielder Ted Manwar- ing said as the Rams regrouped for their final practice FTiday. 
Manwaring. W’illis, JB Steve Jewas- ko, SS Terry Salazar, 2B Mike Ruiz,, IB 
Steve Hill and catcher Willie Frantzen all graduated at Northside Stadium 
Thursday night. 
Manwaring will carry the hottest bat in the series into tonight's game. He has four hits in the first two outings, a 
‘-ingle and an RBI double in each game. His .294 playoff average is just three points under his regular-season a\erage for 27 games, so iie is consis­ tent. 
Overhand 

He says his hitting in this series is largely due to the Roosevelt pitchers, 
“ coming straight overhand, which is my kind of pitching, although I usually hit the curve, loo.” 
He is one of those real rarities in baseball — a left-handed thrower and right-handed batter. Richard Garcia of 
South San is another, but you do not see it much. Ted batted lefty when he started in the Little Leagues, but changed to his current wavs when he was 1o. 
He. like most of the 
.Marshal! starters on what is basically a two-year team (same players), has been in 12 playoff games now. 
“ The crowds definitely make the difference,” he said of the comparison to regular-season play. 
“ The momentum of the games are totally different because the crowds are. At the beginning of a playoff game. I’m nervous, but it soon goes away. 

Jay day 

If you hear Jay baseball Coach 
Roger Tatsch coininent, “ We could beat those guys,” at tonight’s 
Roosevelt-Marshall city title game you can believe him. 

In fact, Tatsch could have said the same thing last week when there were four teams instead of just two in the Class AAAA playoffs. 

Despite a 15-12 record and Just the fourth-best overall record in the 
3o-AAAA standings. Jay is probably the only team in city history to beat five district champions in a single season. 

The Mustangs stopped 29-A AAA champion South San Antonio in the season opener, 8-3; split with Mar­ shall of their own loop (o-7, o-5); scored a 4-3 victory over Jefferson in the game preceding the District 
31-AAA A champs' 21-game winning streak, and won one out of three from 32-AAAA kingpin Roosevelt 
(7-8, 3-5, 2-1). 

Also, another of their non-district wins was a 3-1 triumph over TCIL 
3-A.AA pennant winner Central 
Catholic. 

“ .As far as a hitting team, we are stronger than at tlii.s time a year ago, although we are going to have to hit the ball a lot better than we did tlu' last game {Roosevelt won a 5-2 game last 
V\t'dnesday). We have to get our hits when we hav’e people on base instead of when there are two out.” 
Marshall Coach Denny Ivey echoes that feeling. “ We’ve got to hit with runners on. We’re capable of hitting better than we’ve shown in the playoffs. Roosevelt is the type of team that does a good job of moving the runners around and we have to get the key hits in order to win this one.” 
While Manwaring has bt‘en a two- year regular in baseball, his best sport is football, where the 6-o, 163-pounder has been a two-time All-District free safety. He has accepted a colli'ge grid scholarship to Wharton Junior (College. 
Last fall, in his third season as a starter, he intercepted six passes, was third-leading tackier (seven solos, 7.‘i assists) on the whole team and won the 
“ Hatchet Award” for most outstanding big plays during the season. 
Big plays are what will be needed tonight, too.

XEVV YORK - Darryl Daw­ kins of the Philadelphia 7Hers and Maurice Lucas of the Port­ land Trail Blazers were fined 
$2,5oo each by National Basket­ ball Association Commissioner 
Lawrence ¥. O’Brien Friday as a result of their fight during 
Thursday’s night’s playoff game. 

O’Brien notified the two players of their fines by telegram and also warned coaches Gene Shue of the 76ers and Jack Ramsay of the Trail Blazers to avoid any similar incidents during the balance of the championship series. 
“ Your conduct could have resulted in a serious injury to another player and it created the potential for a vio­ lent crowd reaction that might have led to a serious injury to innocent spectators,” O’Brien told the |)laycrs. 
“ The type pf conduct you displayed last night will not he tolerated by the 
NB.A. You are hereby informed that any similiar action on your part during tlie remainder of the series will be dealt with even more severely.”

GARDEN CITY. N.Y. (A P) - .lohn 
Y. Brown, former owner of the Ken­ tucky Colonels of the defunct American 
Basketball Association, has agreed to rework tlic schedule of payments due from the teams that bought him out while arranging last summer’s ab­ sorbí ion of four ABA tt*ums into the 
National Basketball .Association, 

Brown, who now owns the NB.A Buf­ falo Braves, sold tin* Kentucky fran- 

 chise for $2.8 million. He was due to receive the first payment of $1.5 mil­ lion June 1 from the New York Nets, 
D('nver Nuggets, San Antonii» Spurs and Indiana Paeers. 
But the four ABA survivors have been experiencing financial {jroblems and to case their situation, Newsday reported that Brown bad agn‘ed to accept half the $1.5 millinn tliat was due June I with the other half payable

ASSOCIATED PRESS 
ATLANTA — Dave Stockton, who won two PGA national championships with some matchless scrambling, resorted to his trouble-taming specialty for a three- under-par 69 that staked him to a tie for the second round lead FY’iday in the weather- plagued, $2oo,ooo Atlanta Classic golf tour­ nament. 
“ I can already read what you’re going to say about me scrambling,’’ Stockton grinned after posting a 
137 total, seven under par for two rounds over the 

G O L F S C O H E S , F a ^ e >( 

 hilly, leg-straining Atlanta Country Club course. He shared the top spot with former U.S. Open champion 
Lou Graham and Mac McLendon. 
“ I ’m hitting my irons good and Pm putting as good as 1 can possibly putt,” Stockton said. 
“ But I ’m frustrated by my driver. 1 have absolu­ tely no idea what’s going to come off it — left, right, what 
Almost constantly he was faced with potential disaster. He once one-putted for double bogey. He was saved from going out of bounds when another shot hit a tree and bounced back into play. He shanked one shot out of bounds, but noted "it was a good, solid shank. Went a pretty good ways. Almost into somebody’s house.” He hit o ik * apjnoach shot through the top of a tree, causing a minature shower from the wet leaves—-and then birdied the hole. 
Fin ley cu ts tick et p rice 

OAKLAND (A P) — Charles O. Finl(*y, owner of the Oakland A’s, announced Friday he is cutting ticket prices in half for Monday through Thursday games in hopes of raising attendance. 
“ I know that eventually there will be only one baseball team in the Bay Area. Pd like to be that club. I think this move proves my sincerity.” said 
Finley, whose .American League team competes in the same market with the National League’s San 
Francisco Giants. 
The A’s have drawn 153,999 fans in 22 dates this year, the Giants 183,999 for 17 dates. 
Finley made his announcement at a news confer­ ence held alongside a hotel pool, saying that “ tilings are so bad that 1 couldn’t afford to hold the conference inside the hotel.” 
The .A’s owner said the club lost $699,999 last season and, “ If things don’t get better. I’ll lose $1 million this yt-ar, and I donl know where Pi! gel the mon('y. I don’t have it.” 
The A’s ticket prices Monday through Thursday will range from $2.5o for lower level box s(*ats lo $! for bleacher seats the rest of the season. Tickets wiU remain at full price, with a $5 top on Friday, 
Saturday and Sunday.

Singles.

Indy fever grows 

ASSOClATtO 
INDIANAPOLIvS - Race fever starts almost the instant you cross the state line from Michi­ gan, from Kentucky, from Ohio, from Illinois. As you approach dead-center it becomes a de­ luge, a Mosaic in black and white. 

Dead center Indiana is Indianapolis, the home of the black-and-white checkered flag, the STP oval with the 
“ Welcome Race Fans” tag, the wide- tired hot rod. the beer-clutching motorcyclist, the bare-chested boy and his bare-bellipd girl 
Indianapolis Motor Speedway’s po pulation during the months from June to April IS about 15,ooo. During the first 3’ 2 weeks in May each year it grows to about 1o times that number 
.And each Memorial Day weekend it explodes to close to half a million 
.All for the chance to see and h**ar 33 dn\er.> careen around 2V2 miles of as­ phalt for about three hours 
Those three hours can be almost an- tirlimaetic whrn the race is run as it is supposi’d to be. A safe, accident-free race somi'how leaves a portion of the multitude feeling cheated, as though it had paid not for the sheer beauty of precision control of machines but for the flaming, shrieking moment that turns artibtry into.ashes 
Those three hours are the center­ piece — but at the same time they are a small part of the scenario played out in this heartland of conservatism. 
Only a few' hundred feet from the track Itself and the pits sits Gasoline 
Alley where surgeons with wrenches hover protectively over their $1oo,oo(1 creations. 

TOM SNEVA and his Indy ear 
Upsets galore

 beaten were Alabama.’s Jeff Rnbinspn, 
South Carolina's Chris Mayette. Mia­ mi’s John Eagleton and fourth-seeded 
Bill Maze of Stanford

I3th-seeded Eagleton 6-1. 6-2 in the second round. 
“ I was loose.” said AIcKown, who' has not lost a match in the tourney. 
“ My game is keeping the ball in play.”

Seed soiled 

 losS to Lewis Friday and added some recom­ mendations. 

Tired 

“ I was tired,” said Gottfried, who had given his all in tough matches against Delaney. Lewis and 
Stanford’s Bill Maze in the team competition. “ I just couldn’t find the court. 
“ I’m not trying to say that Lewis didn’t play well against me, but when we finished against 
Stanford last night (in the team title match), I was wiped out,” he explained. 
The NCAA committee decided to use a new format this year, which put a four-day team tournament in front of singles and doubles com­ petition. In the past, a team champion was de fermlned by points the individuals scored in singles and doubles. 
“ It’s like playing the Davis Cup and Wimble­ don in one week,” Gottfried said of the new' for­ mat. “ One day we’re playing for the national championship and the next day we start all over again. 
“ I know the NCAA committee and the people who run the tourney would rather do it all at one time, because it’s convenient for them. 
“ But if they want to see top-caliber tennis in both a team and individual competition, they’ll have to run the tournaments separately.” he concluded, adding that he liked the idea of es­ tablishing a true team champ with a playoff. 
Gottfried was not the only rubbery-legged player on the court Friday. After four days of rain and overcast skies, the sun came out and the humid air was like steam. 
Nine of the 16 seeded players were upset Friday and one seeded doubles team fell by the wayside. 
Some good 
Friday was not all bad for Gottfried, however. 
The TU freshman, who is the younger brother ot pro Brian Gottfried, was one of six players se­ lected on the under-2l Davis Cup team for this summer. 
Also picked were USC’s Manson, Stanford's 
Mitchell and Maze, UCLA’s Taygan and San Jose 
State’s Nial Brash. 
MIKE BRUTON 

McKown uses virtually no power and thrives on precise strokes and passing shots. 
“ It began to take its toll on him 
(Eagleton) because he got tight and started pressing at the net.” com ­ mented McKown, whose passing shots caused Eagleton to kick his racquet in anger several times. 
Iskersky beat Brian Mitchell of Mis­ souri 6-1, 6-4 before he eliminated a tired Maze, 6-4, 6-4. “ He tried every stall tactic in the book.” said Iskersky, who had to wait about 1o minutes dur­ ing the match when Maze requested a new line judge. 
“ I knew I could beat him because he almost lost to (SMU’s Mark) Turpin and I heat Turpin fairly easily.” 
Turpin had match point again st 
Maze in the first round Friday, but the 
Stanford player rallied for a 4-6, 7-6, 
6-4 victory. “ After playing that three- sftter, he should have been tired,” 
Iskersky added. All Maze would say after his loss to Iskersky is. “ No com­ ment.” 
Tony Giammalva won his first two rounds 6-2, 6-7, 6-3 over Miami. Ohio’s 
Steve Kendell and 6-4 6-4 over Califor­ nia’s Charles Stansbury. TU’s No, 2 doubles team of Iskersky and McKown was eliminated by eighth-seeded UCLA duo Fcrdi Taygan and Van Winitsky 
6-1, 6-3 and the T ig ers’ No. 1 unit, 
Gottfried and Giammalva, the tour­ ney’s third seed, advanced with a 3-6, 
7-5. 7-5 victory over a Brash-Brad 
Howe San Jose State team. 
Giammalva will meet Utah’s Kent 
Crawford, 
Iskersky will face 
12th-seeded Tony Graham of UCLA and McKown will have the tough task of playing top-seeded Matt Mitchell of 
Stanford in their opening matches Sa­ turday. Gottfried and Giammalva will play Stanford’s Maze and John Rast in doubles. 
G-P wins it 

SPECIAL TO the e xp ress n e w s 

FALFURRIAS — Gregory-Portland won the second game of a double- header over Falfurrias. 5-1, Friday to win their Class AAA bidistrict scVies two games to one. 

Falfurrias won the opener, 4-3 in eight innings, to necessitate a third game. Gregory-Portland had taken a 
3-2 victory to open the series last 
Tuesday. 

Gregory-Portland will now meet 
Uvalde in the regional finals next week. Arraugements have not yet been determined. 

IRS blues 

 things the government has asked us to do ” 
One of those things Davis pointed out was Title IX. which directs colleges to equalize facilities for men and women 
“ They’re talking about taking up to 
5o per cent of what athletic depart­ ments receive,” said Speegle “ Then you’re talking about schools going out and borrowing money, and I don’t know of any kind of university that’s in a position to do that.” 
If the IRS’ move succeeds, it could be retroactive for three years, thus tripling the cost for many schools. 
“ The devastating part would be col­ lecting the back taxes, let alone having tn include that in your budgeting for the future,” said Chuck Neinas, com­ missioner of the Big Eight. 
Neinas estimated such a tax would cost each of his conference’s schools 
$1oo,ooo a year. 
“ If the IRS takes that attitude on 
. television and radio money, the next step will be looking at our gate re­ ceipts” 
Problem s 
“ We don’t need any more problems like these in intercollegiate athletics.” explained Clyde Walker, athletic dir­ ector of Kansas. 
“ I personally feel this is a prepos­ terous assumption on their part that this is unrelated income. It’s certainly related to our being able to run a suc­ cessful program. 
“ If an adverse decision comes down on TCU or SMU, I don’t think there is any necessity for us to wait for a de­ cision. This is a very serious threat to the future of intercollegiate athletics.” 
Directly affected would be the 
NCAA’s $18 million football contract with ABC; NBC and TVS* $5 million contract with college basketball; bowl agreements worth about $15 million, and conference agreements to televise basketball games. 
And if one of the IR S’ test cases works then, theoretically, it will be applicable to almost every university. 
“ So far everything they (IRS) have told us goes against us,” said Davis. 
“ We’re liable for the income they say. 
“ It’s hard to understand, though, because the money we receive goes into education. 
Political 

“ But I think this matter will end up in the political arena, not the legal arena. Look at Michigan; they put 
1oo,ooo people into their stadium on 
Saturdays. Those people are going to be up in arm s.” 
Does that kind of grass roots support encourage Davis? 
“ I’d like to say yes,” he laughed, 
“ but you never know when you’re dealing with the federal government. 
“ And if you think it'd hurt confer­ ence schools, which split television and radio revenue eight or nine ways, what do you think it’ll do to independents like Notre Dame and Penn State who take it all in themselves? 
“ Then you’re talking about seven figure numbers for the three year per­ iod." 
Why were SMU and TCU two of the schools audited? “ Because we’re in the town where the IRS is located, I think,” said Davis. 
Checked 

“ I wish they had checked someone else (outside the SWC),” said Speegle. 
“ And I hope the congress and people respond for us.” 
If the existence of collegiate athletics is actually threatened by this move, chances are good that universities would have the political and ground level power to stop it. 
If, however, the threat is real and the 
IRS successful, the Saturday matinee could again become an American In­ stitution.

Big race tonight 

A starting spot in the second annual T exas 
Race of Champions will be on the line when drivers take to the track 
Saturday at 8 p.m. at Pan 
American Speedway. 

The victor in the 6o-lap main event wjll be guar­ anteed a spot at the 
TROC this October at the 
Texas World Speedway. 

Miss TWS 1977, Yolan­ da De Los Santos and 
TWS Vice 
P resident 
Mike Connors will be on hand Saturday night. In addition to the main event, fans will see a full program of stock car and figure eight racing in all four classes. Gates open at 6 p.m. and time trails begin at 7 p.m.

Volf 

A TLA N TA (A P I — Second-round scores F rid a y In the $2oo,ooo Atlanta Classic golf tournam ent on the 
6,883-vard, par-72 Atlanta Country Club course; 
M ac McLendon 
6 8 69— 137 
U.S . n etters sca rce 

PARIS (AP) — Stan Smith dismissed Juergen 
Fassbender of West Germany 6-4, 6-3, 7-5 Friday and completed a little band of four Americans in the last 
32 of the French Open Tennis Championships. 
They were all that remained of the 27 Americans who set out at the start of the week. The rest fell in the first two rounds, many of them bemused by the red clay courts of the Roland Garros grounds, slower than any big tournament surface in the United 
States. 
The other American survivors were Harold Solo­ mon, Brian Gottfried and Tom Gullikson, left-hand­ ed member of the Onalaska, Wis., twins. 

Jeff Borowiak and Bill Scanlon were eliminated 
Friday. Raul Ramirez of Mexico, a semifinaUst last year, outplayed Borowiak, of Berkeley, Calif., 6-3, 
6-3, 6-2, Peter Elter, 18-year-old West German, ousted Scanlon of Dallas 4-6, 7-6. 6-4, 6-4 in a match interrupted by darkness overnight.

.SPECIAL TO THE EXPRESS-NEWS 
GEORGE W EST - The Kenedy 
Lions swept their bidistrict series from 
George West Thursday night by dub­ bing the Longhorns with a 16-hit at­ tack, 16-2. 
Kenedy, now 26-6 for the season, will play Hebbronville in a rematch of last year's Class AA regional finals. 
First game is set for 7:3o p.m. next 

Tuesday in Hebbronville. Second con­ test is at 7:3o p.m. in Kenedy, then a third game, if necessary, will be at 7:3o p.m. Friday at a site yet to be deter­ mined. Tickets are $1 and $2 at the gate.

SPECIAL TO THE EXPRESS-NEWS 
WHARTON - The Uvalde Coyotes hit the 3o-victory mark and won their 
Class AAA bidistrict series over 
Whatton with a 9-3 victory in the second game of a doubleheader 
Thursday night, 
Wharton had beaten the Coyotes in the opener by the same score, 
Uvalde sent 12 men to the plate in the third inning of the nightcap and scored six runs. The Pack had six hits, all singles, in the big explosion, including two by Vann McElroy. 
Brian McLaughlin went 3-for-4, 
Steve Rambie 2-3, including a double, and Oscar Alejandro 2-4. 
Left-hander Richard Contreras scat­ tered six hits to get the victory, 
Uvalde’s 3oth against only four losses. 

In the opener, Rambie went 3-for-4 to start a five-hit day and Greg Kolinek had a perfect 3-for-3. Joe Sansom was the losing pitcher for the first time this year. 
Uvalde becomes the first AAA area team since Eagle Pass in 197o to get past the bidistrict level and into regionals, where they will meet the 
Gregory-Portland-Falfurrias winner. 
G-P leads that series, 1-o, going into a twin bill Friday.

Tou rnament at Falcon Lake nex t weekend.

Sale of b lack b ass 

Fish m arket sales of largem ou lh b ass continu e in Tex as u nder a two- y (*ar-old law tliat was not challenged b y a repeal du ring the legislativ e ses­ sion now drawing to a close. 
Two y ears ago politicians passed a law which permits the sale of game fish, su ch as largem ou th b ass and flat head catfish, if the fish are im ­ ported into Tex as. 
It wasn’t long b efore b lack b ass from 
Alex ieo and flatheads from Lou isiana and Alississippi b egan reaching some mai kets in Tex as. According to a law enforetmieiit officer with the Parks and 
Wildlife Department, Pace Fish Com­ pany of Browu s\ ille is importing ab ou t 
35 per cent of all th<' b lack b ass b ein.g sold ill Tex as markets. 

**.As fa r a s we ca n tell, the sa le nf ba ss ha sn't dev elo ped into a pro blem,” he sa id. 

'Pile law eiiforeemenl div ision of Hit* dt'iiartmi'nt do es no t hav e a great deai of eontrol ov er the marketing of the fish. Officials can cheek sales slips to determine the origin of tile fish. That's ab ou t all. 
Alost of tin* liass b eing imported u u - dou idedlv are coming from reserv oirs su ch as Lake Gu errero, where eom- mt*reial fishermen are activ e mu ch of the y ear. 
The fishermen u se monofilament gill nets to catch b ass.

Yo ung acto r g ets big TV break 

Alice (Undo Lavin) takes a fob singing in a club and is arrested with two other women (Liberty Williams, left, and Caren Kaye, right) for soliciting on “ Alice,’* tonight at 
8 :3 o on Channel 5. 

Kevin Brophy is going to have a chance to prove himself early in his act­ ing career. 
Last Sunday evening, 
ABC aired a 9o-minute mystery motion picture called ‘‘Lucan.” It vias 
Kevin’s television acting debut. 
This show is a pilot for 
ABC and is scheduled to replace one of its falter­ ing shows at mid-season in January. 
However, when the ratings were in for the week, this picture ended up as the third highest watched television show of the week. Maybe it will 

On the Air 
Bv LEON 4 P4 PPAS 
TV Editor 

 be on sooner than Ja n ­ uary, should another show come in weak. 
Ex citing time 
“ This is a very exciting time for me.” said the young actor during a re- ct'Ut telephone conversa­ tion. ‘‘1 feel very excited. 
It is fantastic.” 

And it is unusual for a 
2J-year-old newcomer to pick up a lead in a tele­ vision series. 

Born in Salt Lake City. 
Brophy said he moved to 
California when hs was nine years old. “ I at­ tended the California In- stiluie of the Arts’ said

Commercial banks boost prime lending rate 

NKW YOR K (A P ) — A number of major commercial banks across the country bm>sied their prime lendini; rate Friday from fiV-2 fi‘*4 P^'r cent, the second time this month the rate has jump<'d a quarter-point. 
The move, which had been expected, was irigR ered by Federal R eserve figures released Thursday showing the average rate on'commercial paper — 

 shori.*term loans betwt'cn corporations 
— was rising. 
Among banks increasing the lending rate In their most credit-worthy busi­ ness customers were Citibank, the na­ tion’s second largest com m ercial bank, Chase Manhattan Bank, ranked third, and Chicago’s Continental Illin­ ois National Bank & Trust Co., the seventh largest bank. 

But others, including firstranked 
Bank of America, did not join the trend. “ We’re studying the .situation,” a spiikesman said in a telephone inter­ view from the bank’s San Francisco headquarters. “ We are aware of the moves in the market place.” 

Citibank, which computes its prime rate by using a combination of factors 

Including the price of com m ercial paper, led the way Friday as it did on 
May 13 when it boosted the rate % point to 6>/ 2 per cent. 

Most banks gave the same reason for the increase. 

“ We are raising the prime because the cost of the funds we borrow is going 

 up, and we fee! it’s not going to hurt the demand for loans from our bank, relative to other banks,” said Dick 
Peterson, chief economist for i'hicago’s Continental Illinois, 

According to Citibank’s chief econ­ omist, Lief Olsen, the rate “ is not dir­ ectly linked to consumer loan rates. 
That’s like saying an increase in the 

 price of bananas would lead to an in- crea.se in ladit‘s’ dresses. 
“ The only thing the two have in common is that they are both prices and they may both rise,” he said. 
The prime rate also is influenced by demand for loans, which bankers say has been sluggish in New York, lag­ ging behind the increase now being seen in other parts of the country.

Market losses bring 
Dow below 9oo

J O N E S IN r > V S T R Ii l . l , J L V E H J IO B E ; N . ir . S E . IN E > «3C 

NKW Y U K K ( A P ) — 
The stock market com­ pleted a week of sharp losses Friday with a drop that carried the Dow 
Jones industrial average below 9oo for the first time in more than 16 months. 
The widely recognized average of 3o blue chips fell 9.24 to 898.83, its first close under 9oo since it stood at 898.69 on Jan. 7, 
1976. 
That stretched the 
Dow’s loss for the week to 31.63 points. 
Losers outpaced gainers by about a 7-4 margin on the New York 
Stock Exchange. 
Big 
Board volume slowed to 15.73 million shares from 18.62 million 
Thursday, with the mar­ ket doing little to keep investors from opting for an early start on the 
Index predicts economic gains will continue 

W A S H IN G T O N s t a r S t R V iC t 

WASHINGTON 
- 
Fcnnomir gams will con­ tinue for at least the next tow months, a goM'rn- nient index indicated 
Fridax 
The 
(dinmiTce 
D(‘- 
{»artment r('i>"i't<‘d a mod­ erate rise of 11.o |H'r ciml m its index of “ leading indicators,“ This index consists of statistics that usually rise and fall in ad\aiiee of broad move­ ments m the economy. 
' 
It is list'd as a fore­ casting tool, although it is not foolproof. The (l.o per cent rise m the imlex last month was the third 

111 a row. hut It was smaller than the iiu'rease of 1,9 per cent m March and 9 8 per cent m P'ch- ruary. 
'I'he index de­ clined 12 per cent in 

January, during the cold wave, but rebounded 
((uiekly. 

Components 

Four of the 
It) components of the index that were available for 
Friday’s preliminary re- jioiT registered gains, five moved adversely and one was unchanged from 
.March. .Although more components declined than imiiroved, the weighting formula pro­ duced an over-all gain. 
Tlu' biggest gain was a mixed blessing. .Sensitive lirices of crude materials rose faster in .April than in March. This was taken as a sign of rising de­ mand, but It also indi­ cated strong inflationary pressures. 
. Other contfMinents that 

 improved were vendor performance (slower de­ liveries indicated rising demand), contracts and orders for plants and etjuipmenl, and the mon­ ey supply in eonstanl dollars. 

Adverse 

The components mov­ ing adversely were the average work week, the change in total liquid as­ sets. stock prices, new orders for consumer pro­ ducts and materials, and building permits. The decline in building per­ mits was the bigge.st ne­ gative item ill the index. 
The job layoff rale was unchanged from March to April. 
The department also reported a rise of o.7 per cent in its index of 
“ coincident indicators.”

OPEN MEMORIAL DAY 

 rUSMStt 
—r —- rr— 
< 

Memorial Day holiday 
^^eekend. 
The Dow’s drop below 
9oo drew some attention on Wall Street because it represented a round- number milepost for the average’s decline since the start of the year, when it stood at 1,oo4.65. 
But some technical an­ alysts argued that it didn’t necessarily repre­ sent the cracking of an important level of sup­ 

 port for the market. 
They noted that the average had moved with­ out resistance through 
9oo on its way up in the rally of early 1976. 
As expected, the mar­ ket was faced Frid ay morning with the news of a prime rate increase by 
New Y ork’s Citibank, from 61/i to 6% per cent. 
The increase, the second this month, spread fairly quickly 

 through the banking in­ dustry, although there were some holdouts such as California’s Bank of 
America. 

Investors had had con­ siderable advance notice that another boost was likely in the basic charge on blue-chip business loans. 

But it nevertheless seemed to set a gloomy mood for the market. 
Ag groups attack proposed hiring laws 

Migrant workers and 
South Texas growers and packers attacked pro­ posed federal changes in regulations on employ­ ment of foreign agricul­ tural workers Friday. 
The two grou{)s, how­ ever, challenged the pro­ posed changes from dif­ ferent points ot view 

 during hearings held by the U.S. Department of 
Labor at the San Antonio 
Convention Center. 
The hearings here are part of six being held in the U.S. to take testi­ mony from interested parties on revisions of federal law on employ­ ment of aliens for tern- 
Orange juice at new high 

Orange juice concen­ trate reached new histor­ ic high prices this week of over 88 cents per pound basis the nearby 
Ju ly delivery, as the market continued to be supported by healthy usage statistics and the poor yield of the late season of Valencia or­ anges. 
Prices at the retail le­ vel had yet to reflect the advance in futures but might do so soon should 
Florida processors raise their ‘card price’ to dis­ tributors. 

Trading in cocoa this week reflected a tight­ ness of physical supplies in London that is rooted in a delay of shipments from West African ori# gins. 
The July contract in 
New York recovered to a point Just shy of the previous contract highs in sympathy with the huge jump in prices on the London terminal. 
R elief should be com­ ing with the arrival of supplies in London and 

COMMOMTY 
RBFORT 
Furntshed by (^eratd S. 
Cobn, vice |»resid«fti, sales dhKutn. Sat» .\a- tttfiia 
Hache Hal- sev Stuart Inc. 

 the expiration of the May contract there. 
Grain crop prospects continued to be favorable and corn futures once again fell to new seasonal lows this week. 
Planting of the new crop has been running ahead of schedule and has now reached virtual completion. 
While additional rain­ fall would be most wel­ come, early stands are in generally strong condition. 
Krueger wants cover-up probe 

SPECIAL TO THE EXPRESS NEWS 
W ASHINGTON. D C. 
— U.S. R ep. Bob Krueger next week will explore ways to investigate alle­ gations the Carter ad­ m inistration has at­ tempted to suppress a study indicating the na­ tion’s natural gas supply is not as inadequate as previously portrayed. 
“ The public deserves the best information that 
ER DA (Energy R esearch and Development Ad­ ministration) can offer,” 
Krueger said. 
“ And we want to make certain that no one in the executive branch might in any way be attempting to limit the public’s right to know,” he said. 
Krueger’s concern stems from reports claiming the administra­ tion attempted to redir- 

 ect findings of a study group commissioned by 
ER DA to determine how much natural gas will be available, regardless of price. 
The group, the Market 
Oriented Program Plan­ ning Study, supposedly put together a report showing there would be no natural gas shortage if prices were not regulated by the government since regulations minimize profits that could be used to finance further ex­ ploration for gas.

TINDALL k SON 

Pontiac, CiMC 

 porary farm work. 
Charles K. 
R ivera, executive vice president of the Texas Citrus and 
Vegetable Growers and 
Shippers Assn. in Har­ lingen. said the proposed changes would have a disastrous effect on the economy of South Texas. 
“ W'e can’t get enough domestic workers in the fields durin.g harvest,” 
R ivera said. “ We have to rely on workers from 
Mexico to get the crops in. 
“ These changes, which would cut down a growers ability to get alien workers when they’re needed, w ill drastically affect the job situation for both alien and domestic workers by jnitting a lot of growers and packers out of busi­ ness.” strict 
Jose Saldana of the 
United Farm Workers union in San Juan said the federal law should be made more strict and keep all alien workers out of South Texas fields. 

MONDAY —- The Dow Jones Indus­ trial Average dipped to a loss of 13.4o, biggest loss in over six months (since 
Nov. 5. 1976). Volume of trading was relatively light at 18.29 million shares, smallest in two weeks. This indicated lack of buying interest. News items lilted heavily to the bearish side. Not a single one of the 3o blue chips making up the Dow advanced. 

TUESDAY - The Dow Industrials penetrated below their 1977 April low point and closed at 912.4o for a loss of 
4.66. This was the fourth straight los­ ing sesaion, taking the average back to its level of Jan. 9. 1976. Chartists noted that the N Y SE index of all common stocks closed the session at 53.44, and was still holding above its April low’ of 
52.96. Gold shares which often counter the downtrend also lost ground. 

WEDNESDAY — Losses continued for five successive days. Selling vo­ lume increased with 74 per cent on the downside as the D JIA posted a loss of 
9.16. Only one of the 15 most active 
“ We hear the cry from 'stocks scored an advance. The N YSE the growers that they ittdex lost o.49, closing at 52.95 one can’t find domestic 
^ 
, 
THUR SDAY — The Dow Jones In­ dustrial Average held, temporarily at least, above the psychological 9oo line, and closed at 9o8.o7 for a gain of 4.83. 
The Dow lost 38.67 points in the past five sessions. In the whole market, declines exceed advances better than 7 
— 6, however the N YSE index, a mea­ sure of all common stocks, closed up 

 workers for their fields,” 
Saldana said. “ That is a lie. Unemployment is more than 1o per cent in our area. 
“ But the growers don’t want to pay a living wage to the workers. They can pay the alien worker less. 

o.1o at 53.o5. Volume was relatively light, but upside volume led downside better than 3 — 2. After the close the nation’s money supply was reported to have advanced $1.4 billion in the week ended May 11 over the previous week. 

FRIDAY — The Dow broke belnw the 9oo level, closing at 898.83, for a loss on the day of 9.24. The N YSE In­ dex closed at 52.68, losing o.37 and still holding above its June 7, 1976, low of 
52.52. The City Bank of New York City announced an increase in its prime lending rate to 6% per cent from 6 V2 per cent. This, along with the previous day’s notification of an increase in the nation’s money supply, cast a pall on the market. 

SUM M AR Y — The Dow Jones In­ dustrial Average landed at a new 
15-month low, going back to January' 7, 
1976. It suffered the second largest loss of the year, down 31,63 points. Volume of trading for the regular five-day wet'k was below par, indicating lack of both buying and selling interest. 
Prices just seemed to sink from their own weight. 

R ANGE — High was made on Mon­ day at 928.17. Low was made on Friday at 896.29. Close, Friday, 898.83. Loss on the week, 31.63. Volume, all shares traded on the N Y S E , 93.4o million shares.

Ft. Worth Livestock 

FO R T WOR TH, Tex. (A P ) — Compared with last week, slaughter cows steady to 
5o lower with decline on utility. Slaughter bulls steady to 1.oo Lower, full downturn on yield grade 1. Feeder steers steady to 
SO lower. Steer calves opened SO lower, late sales steady to firm. Feeder heifers and heifer calves stedy to 5o lower. Stock cows and pairs 1 oo 2.oo Lower, Demand moderate, trading fairly active. R un in eludes around 28 percent slaughter cows, 
5 percent slaughter calves and bulls. Bal ance mostly good and low choice feeders. with good supply of yearlings on offer.

Chicago Grain 

CHICAGO (A P ) - Old crop soybean, meal and oil futures prices declined sharply on (he Chicag o Board of Trade 
Friday 
The three old crop soybeans deliveries were down 23 cents at the final bell w hile soy oil declined the allow able da ily lim it of 1oo points, or 
I cent a pound. The nearby m eal futures lost S5 a ton. 
The o vera ll weakness ot the com plex tended to Influence selling of g rains. How ever, Ihere also was a weather factor in volved. C om , w heal and oats futures were down ’ * to 
T '7 cents. Iced broilers were sold on the weakness in g rains and meal as w ell as expectations of confín uinq hig h production and lost SO points, or 
' Í cent a pound 
The seliing in the com plex was in 
(luenced by several factors. There was some disappointm ent that export com m itm ents for the last reporting week, ended M ay 15, were not hig her. Meal prices were soft abroad. Also, heavy s ell­ ing set off by a com mission house repon idly acting for foreig n Interests, sent prices down 27 cents at one tim e. 
There were several attem pts to ra lly the soybean com plex, but only new crop 
” ienths attracted buyers in any num bers. 
Spreading a c tiv ity In selling old crop and iHiving i» w crop months, was very active in the com plex. 
The w eather was a sm all seiling factor 
I” the com plex but it aHected corn, wheat and oats trade to a g reater deg ree. Rain tel I over a wide area of the M iddle West ug ain and m ore was expected over the weekend

‘Chic’ home featured in Thousand Oaks 

Trees . . . trees . . . trees. 
You can plant them and you can replant them, but trees in their natural environ­ ment are something spe­ cial. That’s why Thousand 
Oaks is something special. 
Builders here built around them, between them, did ever­ ything they could to save them lor you so that you could come home to a home in a neighbor­ hood with the feeling oi warm country living that only trees can create. 
Finest cra ftsma nship 
Nestled among the gentle slopes of Thousand Oak'^ are some of the loveliest new' homes in San Antonio by builders who take pride in providing only the finest craftsmanship, quality and new ideas. 
Mike Hcholl, of M. A. Scholl 
Enterprises, is one of those builders. His homes present the feeling of “ now" — the contem­ porary life. His new home at 
1H7KI Ledge Creek is a perfect example of how young ideas and know-how combine to produce the bold, the dramatic, the un­ conventional flair for chic style and functional design. 
A frost('d-glass ('iitry door of art nouxeau design leads into the warm Saltillo-tiled foyer. 
Beyond, a tremendous family room with a glass wall over­ looking a patio deck dominates the lower level. A soaring ceiling with strip lighting for dramatic effects increases the feeling of space. 
A raised hearth and see- through fireplace separate the fam ily room from the living room which looks out into its 

T H O U S A N D O A K S hom e b y M ik e Scholl of M . A. Scholl Enterprises fe ature s the m ost striking o f contem porary stylin gs throu gh out 

 own walled garden. The kitchen and breakfast nook directly off the dining area are finished in warm autumn tones. Fine craft­ ed cabinets and wood trim are in natural stained pecan tones. 
Three large garden windows provide a mini-hothouse effect for growing herbs and potted plants. 
A master bedroom suite is tucked away on the lower le\el of the home. Spacious, tranquil, with large closets for storage, the room becomes a retreat from the busy work day. The master bath has a large sunken 

 shower and counter space with two lavabos and elegant wall covering to blend with the warm wood tones used throughout the home.

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS— Saturday Mav 28 1977 
Sc otts wood a re a ope ning in Ca me lot 

K\cr notice a neighborhood so eye-catching and pleasant, from the moment you enter, that you feel the place deserves a name of its own? 
Hay Ellison felt the way about a new iieiuhborhood in the f'amelot area and decided to call it Scottswood. 
Emphasis on building 

The entrance monument, with the 
Scottswood name on it, hasn’t even completed yet because all the construction emphasis is on building new homes at the heart of the Scotls* uood imaKc. 
SlrikinM. contemporary designs — with soaring cathedral ceilings; fire­ places; spacious kitchens with the 

ClASSirilO DISPlAt 

 most, modern appliances, including microwave cooking; and a whole array of other features — make this new neighborhood so tjnique. 
Scottswood. like Camelot itself, is outside the city limits, offering econo­ mic advantages from the outset in terms of no city taxes. Despite the ab­ sence of city taxes, Scottswood is lo­ cated with ideal proximity to the mag­ nificent Windsor Park Mall and many large supermarkets, drug stores and specialty shops established in the area. 
Another “ bonus” that comes as standard with the vScottswood life style is the nearness of excellent schoids which cover the whole range, from grade school through high school, where the emphasis is on educational excellence and \aried extracurricular activities which encourage leadership. 
MSPiiV euiitntb bit^iAY 

 social adjustment and -initialive. 
Energy-saving packages in each Hay 
Ellison home are designed to save up to *3 or even more on utility costs. The 
Ellison energy package includes extra wall and celling insulation which ex­ ceeds VA/FHA standards; double-pane windows: special caulking and interlocking thresholds around win­ dows and doors; power attic ventila­ tors; and energy-efficient central air conditioning and heating systems. 
Quality is the keynote for Hay E l­ lison’s diverse model selection in 
Scottswood, featuring attractive brick exteriors, professional landscaping, privacy fencing and patios perfect for weekend barbecues. Interiors are highlighted by carpeting, decorator wall fabrics, all-electric kitchens with microwave ovens and woodburning 
EiiBPHTBiPlI? ------- 

Scottswood is the kind of neighborhood that de­ serves a name of its own, although it is located in the Camelot area. Home seekers who wish to visit 

 this new community will find information at the 
Camelot sales office on New World Drive. 

 c iA is in io 

 fireplaces as standard in many models. 
.Another very important plus for homebuyers who previously have run into developers who left them “ high and dry’’ after the close of the sale is 
Ray Ellison’s extraordinary customer service operation in which Ellison representatives are fully responsive to 
WiPlAV---------- 

 buyer needs for a full year following the purchase of a new Ray Ellison home. 

Military commuters will find Scotts­ wood located squarely between Fort 
Sam Houston and Randolph A FB and with easy access to the N.E. IH 35 
Expressway, which gives a direct shot 

 downtown and the pleasures of San 
•Antonio.

Specialist 

Von wouldn’t hire an 
('icetrieian to repair your iH'ating system, nor a ear|)t>iiler to install a new boiler. Modern techno­ logy in each field of seieriee and industry is now so complex, slat<‘s the 
Better 
Heating- 
Cooling Council, that the 
“ generalist” (formerly known as a jack of all trades) can waste expen­ sive hours by the old 
"trial and error” meth­ od. A properly trained heating contractor with solid experience behind him can quickly appraise your heating needs witli- out making costiy mis­ takes at your expense. 
Especially is this true of the new iieal pumps, where each brand has Us own special circuitry. If you have one of these modern ’‘miracles" that needs to be repaired, be sure the man you call has been specifically trained in .servicing that brand. 
Such units operate under stringent specifications of temperature and pres­ sure, and the mechanic must know the charac­ teristics of your model.

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS— Saturday May 28 197 7 
Pecan trees having scab, gal l probl ems 

Page * 7-D 

By TERK Y W ILB O I RN 
COUNTV EXTtNSION HORTICULTURIST 
For some reason it seems that, this St)ring, pecan trees sure are lia\in<i their share of insect and disease problems. 
Two problems quite prevalent now are the galls eaused by the pecan phylloxera and the fungus disease called scab. L e t's hope you have neither problem on your trees, but exeryone that has pecan trees should be aware ol these probknus and possi­ ble control measures. 
Produces galls 
The pecan phylloxera produces galls on new pecan growth. Leases, twigs and nuts may be affected 

(»alls are cnn^picuous sw ellings which ma\ be 1/lfl to oiu* nich in dia­ meter. Tiiey are caused l)\ a sofl-bo- di('d insect closely related to aphids. 
I’hslloxera jTasses tlu' W inti'r in ttu' egg stage in bark cresices. in Si)ring. the tiny nymph emerges and fe('ds on t(*nder young growth, secreting a sub­ stance which stimulates plant tissue to deselop into galls. 
•\fter maturing, the adult deposits numerous eggs inside the gall or on pecan leaves. Young nymphs of the succeeding generation develo|> within the gall, which splits in one to three weeks and liberates them. Several generations follow during Summer and 
Pall, as long as thei'e is fresh, young growth on the tree. 
Pach generation requires lour to lue 

 weeks. Dormant oil spray recom ­ mended for ol)scure scale control will reduce manifestation levels of jdiyl- loxiM'a when thoroughly applied to tree trunks and major limbs during the 
\\ inter. 
Pecan seab. a fungus disease, is present 1\ (piite severe on some var­ ieties. 
Pt'can scab is the most 
(U'structive disease of pecans in I'exas. 
The fungus invates the young, rapidly growing shoots and leaves and later the developing nuts. Severely iidi'cted nuts on highl\ scap-susceptible var­ ieties drop or fail to devehq), resulting in a total nut crop loss. F.arly season defoliation often occurs in seasons of freiiuent rains and high humidity since these conditions facilitate the rapid development and spread of the scab fungus. 
The scab fungus overwinters in in- lectt'd shoots and in old shucks and leaves in the Spring, when tempera­ ture and moisture conditions becoiiK' tavoral)le, the fungus begins to grow and, within a few days, produces a large number of spores. 
T1k*sl‘ spores are spread by air cur- rt'uts and rain to newly developed leaves on which they germinate and invade the lender tissues. 'Phe fungus producL's a great number of spores on the surfaces of these primary inft'ction 
Sites and spreads throughout the tree, infi'cting other young shoots, leaves and nuts. 
Scab disease development is favored by rainy periods an(l mild tempera­ tures I nder these conditions, spores 

 of the fungus in contact with lht‘ wet surfacL' of a leaflet or nut germinate rapidly, invade the tender tissues and initiate infection within six hours. Le­ sions rL'sulting from tiu'se infection sites l,)t'comt‘ visibk' to the nakt‘d <*ye within sevtn to 14 davs. dei>ending on env ii'onmenlal (onditions. .\ ¡leriod of warm, dry wcatlu'r following infeL tiiUi may retard lesion dev elojmu'nt. 
'Phe control of pecan scab de|>ends primarily on the protection of tender 
U‘af. nut and shoot surfaces with a{)- plications of an effective fungicide. A protective film of fungicidal chemical prevents infections by ke('ping the. spores from developing normally. 
I nfoiiunalely. once the fungus has invaded the tissues, it is no long«*r vulnerable to fungicidt's. 'Pherid'ore, thorough coverage of leaf, nut and shoot surfaces with a fungicidt' must be maintained to pn'vcnt disease <k‘- velopment. Benoym l is a w etiable povviler fungicide must be maintained to pr('V('Ut disease ilevelotnuent. Ben­ oyml is a wettable powder fungicide that is available to homeovviu*rs and vvhii-h can bi usi'd to control scab 
★ ★ ♦ 
If you wish to kei'p up on the latest happenings in the world of horticul­ ture, be sure to watch the “ Good Day” show on KPN.S TV-f) at <5:45 a.m. each 
Friday 
'Phis is a new program for which Bill 
- Shomette is host, and 1 will fie a regu­ lar guest each Friday. This is a live program, and. yes, 1 (lid say “ a.m ,” — not p.m.

G alls or swellings caused by the pecan phylloxera may vary from 1/1o to one inch in diameter and will be found both on the leaves and nutlets. Picture at top demonstrates this.

Gardeners’ Ouestions— Answers 

By TE RRY WILBOURN 
COUNTY EXTENSION HORTICULTURIST 
1 live in the country, and deer seem to love to eat many of the plants I put out. ,A.re there any plants they don't like'* 

.According to fellow 

 horticulturist Ted Fisher of .Austin, there are sev­ eral plants that deer do not particularly like. 
These are century plant, aloe, butterfly bush, box­ wood. cactus. Mexican 

 smoke tree, scotch 

 broom, persimmon, fig, ash, Carolina jessamine, 
English ivy, Washington palm, holly (thorny var­ ieties), jasmine, lupine, magnolia and Chinaberry tree. 

 fan palm, clem atis, 

What is causing the bottom leaves of my tomatoes to turn yellow with brown spots within the yellow area'.^ 

Sounds like either Sep- Blight. Spray regularly 

 torla leaf spot or Early with maneb for control. 

The leaves oil my Benjamin fig are turning yellow and dropping. What could be causing this? 

It’s a good bet you are either overwatering or are giving it insufficient

A TOTALLY NEW LIFESTYLE AWAITS YOU. 

Enter the world of Mission Trace and enter a world in itself. This unique garden home community is proud to announce that Sitterle and Companies, top San 
Antonio home builders, are creating custom garden homes In Mission Trace. In this garden hideaway you'll find total privacy, including 24 hour security for re­ stricted entry Into the development. Plus, year round maintenance that insures a constant professional landscaping image for the entire area. In addition, you'll find that Mission Trace is truly pedestrian ori­ ented with private streets, and walkways throughout the tree studded terrain. You'll also enjoy swimming and tennis in the secure Mis­ sion Trace atmosphere. 
Bring the outdoors in with a choice of a dis­ tinctively different Sitterle floor plans in 2 or 3 bedroom variations. High beam and vaulted ceilings highlight overly spacious living areas, great for relaxing or entertaining. Single or multi-level plans are available, too. However, you must see and feel the elegance of Mission 
Trace to appreciate It. 

<M issio tt ^BQee 
696-3 83 8 

 light. Try modifying these conditions, and, I believe, it will improve. 

Questions on various aspects of lawn, garden or plant care, as weH as landscaping, can be ans­ wered in this column.i 
Please address any corre­ spondence to the colum­ nist himself and not to this newspaper. The columnist requests that all inquiries be made by mail and not by telephone. Correct mailing address is: Down to Earth, c / o Terry Wil- bourn. County Extension 
Horticulturist, Texas Agri- cultval Extension Service, 
2o3 W . Nueva St., Room

Cast pain checkup suggested 

Dear Dr. Thosleson: My son had an athletic injury to his leg. He was put in a leg cast, and a few day s afterward he com­ plained of pain under the cast. Do y ou think the bone was set wrong or what? He doesn’t want to go in because he thinks it might delay the time before he can get out of the cast. What would y ou do? — Mrs. F.W. 

I hope by now y ou hav e decided to take him in for an ex amination. Certain kinds of pain can mean different thing s g oing on u nder the cast, either pressu re points at a bony prom inence or su btle sw elling of tissu o. A 
“ window” can be cu t ou t of the cast to allow the doctor to ex amine the point where the pain ori­ g inates. Casts are u su ally reev alu ated reg u larly any way as a matter of rou tine, so I su spect y ou r qu estion has been ans­ wered for y ou before y ou read this. Allowing the pain to g o u nreported mig ht prolong the time he’s in the cast. 

Companion 

Dear Dr. Thosteson: 
My three-y ear-old has this imag inary compan­ ion she talks to and play s with. She ev en insists that if we bu y a candy bar for her we g et one for this play mate, whom she cu lls “ E lsie.” We hav e become w orried that there may be something wrong , bu t her pediatri­ cian doesn’t seem too concerned. He say s it’s norm al. What do y ou think ? 
It's qu ite normal, and it is not necessarily the 
“ only child” who does this ou t of loneliness for com panionship. 
It is fou nd ju st as m u ch among y ou ng sters who ha\e brothers and sister. 
Rig ht now this has ad­ 

 v antag es for her. She has a companion ov er whom she has m ore or less com plete control. An- toher adv antag e may be the ex tra peice of candy she cons from y ou . 
Blood Pres s ure 

Dear Dr. Thosteson: 
Please find enclosed with this the 35 cents for y ou r booklet on hig h blood pressu re. Also, ju st how hereditary is it? — Mrs. 
G.P. 
Can’t say . .Stu dies show hig h blood pressu re can ru n in families. Often it is the predisposition toward it that is m ost important. I discu ss one stu dy (pag e 9 of booklet) among a g ou p of y ou ng ­ sters with hig her than norm al pre ssu re . No specific cau se cou ld be fou nd, bu t w 11 ov er 8o per cent of them were su bstantially ov erweig ht. 
Their parents were too, so it a ppe a rs that the eating habits are more 
“ inherited” than the dis­ ease. 
It’s obv iou s where we all can beg in making a difference in the w ar ag ainst hig h blood pres­ su re and other heart re­ lated diseases —- rig ht at the dinner table. The booklet y ou wanted is on the way . Allow a week. 
You r letter reached me finally , bu t nex t tim e write to me care of this newspaper, and enclose a stamped, self-addressed env elope. 

What are ulcers ? How can y ou help y ours elf get rid of ulcers and s tay rid of them? Read Dr. Thos fes on's booklet, "How to Heal 
Peptic Ulcers ." For a copy write to him in core of this news paper, enclos ing a long, s elf-addres s ed, s tomped env elope and 25 cents .

BIRTHDAY

Carpet change 

Abdu l two months ag o I took adv antag e of a carpet bale a local department store was hav ing and ordered carpt'ting for the liv ing room/dining room area in my hou siv 
1 paid cash for the carpeting and charg ed the installalion fee. Some men from the store came to ni> iiou se a cou ple of da.v b later and proceeded to mstal! the carpeting . 
Hcl'ore tliey were fiiii.shed, tlu w (It'tcnniiO'd then‘ was» not I'liou g li to cox i'r the whole area. Ni'cdlcss to sa>, ! wa.s \('ry u p.si-t and calhni llic store manag er immediately . 
He apolog iml and said 1 wou ld ha\c to wait abou t a week before be cou ld g el niort' of the .same Im)c carpeting 1 bou g ht. 
It has been nearly six weeks and the dining -room still has no carpeting on it. E\ery time 1 call the manag er he say s I will hav e to wait u ntil the carpeting comes in. 
1 hav e the fi'cliiig I am g etting the ru narou nd, ('an y ou help me? 
MRS. D. V. i:. 

When 
Action-Ex press first contacted the m anager, he said the carpeting still had not come In. The sale was offered at all department store branches nation­ wide and It sold out at most locations. 
The main office has been try ing to track down a store that still has y our ty pe carpeting in stock. 
The manager also said the reason there was not enough carpeting was because y ou originally ordered a contrasting 

 print for the dining room and a solid color for the liv ing room. 
It was not until y ou changed y our mind that the men determined they would not hav e enough carpeting for the whole area. 
,A few day s after Ac­ tion-Ex press contacted the store m anager, he said the carpeting had been found and was on its way to Han Antonio. 
It should he installed by the m iddle of nex t week. 
Paper buy er 

Reference is made to y ou r printed reply in answiT to a qu estion by a reader wlio wanltHl to know if any one eoilt'eted or bou g ht paper. 
We too l)u y all ty pes of pap(*r and pay competitiv e priei‘s. We also pick u p paper in some u istanees where the qu antity is su ffieient. 
BENNY W. MctiEIIEK 
Action-Ex press would like to pass this Informa­ tion along to Its readers. 
Aabco Paper Stock, 8 15 
Ceralv o St., 134-o68 1, also buy s paper. 
The company pay s 
$1.15 for ev ery 1oo pounds of newspaper, $1.25 for 
1oo pounds of computer print out paper. $6 .2o for 
1oo pounds of IBM cards and 7 5 cents for 1oo pounds of corrugated 

 paper. 
“ We also buy all other ty pes ol paper such as office files and the like.“ 
M ctiehee, m anager, said. “ I*rices v ary ac­ cording to the quality of the paper. 
The paper company al­ so prov ides containers to schools to use during their y outh driv es or other clubs interested in hav ing paper driv es.

Why hasn’t the city done any thing to eolleet tliis d(‘bt? The Spu rs ha\e made lieu dlines telling of the millions they hav e spent, so why nu t pay off the debt to the city ?

B. H.

White said under the new

Ol d Charl i e i s a ni ce qui et dri nker 

C A SSELBERRY , Fla. (A P ) - 
Charlie Marshal always knows when iCs race day. That’s the only time the 
1o-year-old horse is denied his usual daily fare of two sixpacks of beer. 

“ Old Charlie will suck all the beer you can give him and never spill a drop,” says ownertrainer 
Sam 
Ridgeway. “ 11 really doesn’t harm him none and seems to make him a happier horse” 

Charlie, whr» also is fond of steaks and cold cuts, is known as “ a nice quiet drinker” at the Seminole Har­ ness Raceway near Orlando, says 
Ridgeway. 

“ There’s nothing to it.” says 
Ridgeway, “ Charlie’s more like a pet hound than a horse. ... He started guz­ zling beer when he was 3 and that was seven years ago.” 
The galloping guzzler’s abstinence 

 on race days is not voluntary since track stewards insist on sobriety. But 
Ridgeway says the dry periods affect 
Charlie so that the horse will start whinnying at the crack of a pop-top. 
Ridgeway’s association with Charlie was interrupted only once when the horse was taken during a claiming race. 
“ I got him back a few months later,” says Ridgeway. “ Charlie’s such a rugged individualist as horses go, if not a downright nut, that nobody else knows how to handle him.” 
Although Charlie has come in fifth in his last eight races, he has a lifetime mark of 2:o7 for the mile run and has earned nearly $4o,ooo in his career. 
“ He’s never been a stakes champion like some other horses I’ve developed, but Charlie’s a good steady trotter.” says Ridgeway. “ His winnings average about $5,ooo and that’s enough to keep the beer flowing.’’

Liz a nd pa ls thinking thin 

By m i l d h j^:d w h i t e a k e r 
Express-NVws Women’s Editor 
Liz Ca rpenter o nce wro te a n a rticle titled “ I Wa s a 
Dro po ut fro m a Fa t Fa rm.” 
“ Not, that IhertKvvas anything wrong with the reducing spa,” she said Friday by pho^e from her home in Austin. “ It was just so deadly boring. 
“ All anybody ever talked about was food, an agonizing subject that should have been avoided.” 
So leave it to Liz — now that her doctor has ordered her to lose weight — to organize her own “ fat farm.” 
This one, however, w ill be known as the “ Think and Shrink lank,” and will Ih* exclusively for 
“ fi'arless fi'wsome friends inter­ ested in filling the evenings with good philosophy 
— books, business and subjects of mutual interest.” 
It happened like this. 
“ Patsy Steves (Mrs. Marshall 

Saturday' 
EXPRESSNEWS 
Scene 

Paget-E 
May 28 1977 

St<*ves of San Antonio), who is a size B or 8 and doesn’t need to lose an ounce but has friends who do, namely me,” said liz, “ is letting us use their home outside Comfort for our Think and Shrink Tank. 
July B to 2o. 
“ After my love affair with the great hors d’oeuvres of the world 
— and enjoying every minute of it 
— my doctor tells me 1 have to lose 3o pounds.” 

The “ fearless fewsome” (limit­ ed due to space available) is a cross-section of 
Liz's many friends from Texas and from years in Washington, D.C., as a 

 writer, lecturer, press secretary to Mrs. Lyndon Johnson and vice president of one of the country’s largest public relations firms. 
For starters, there's Betty Tal- madge "who describes herself as the outgoing wife of the senior senator from Georgia “ notes Liz. 
(They’re divorcing.) 
“ Betty is everybody’s favorite story teller. She knows a lot about business, owns a ham company, 
.uid has written a book titled “ How ti) Cook a Pig.” 
Also coming is Antoinette (Mrs. 
M ark) Hatfield, wife of the Re­ publican senator from Oregon. A former college dean, the pr<*tty 
“ Toni” runs a real estate business 
.in Washington, D.C.. and has written sevt'ral cookbooks. The latest is “ Ke-MARK-able Ke- ci])(‘s,” dedicated to her husl>and. 
Scotty F'itzgerald Smith of Wa­ shington anil Alabama will be tluM'C- Scotty, who has written a number of books, is the daughter of Scott and Zelda Fitzgerald.

Retreat

EL GRECO LEG W RAP in red. blue, black or while canvas print 

25.oo 

Dear Ann: We are a childless couple 
(by choice), and our home is not child-oriented. 
Two couples have ruined recent visits for us by including toddlers and pre-schoolers in late dinner invitations, when they knew that we are not set up for entertaining young children. 
When they go out to a restaurant they get a ba­ bysitter, but when it’s just to someone’s house, they don’t bother. The visits were totally child- dominated and adult conversation was impos­ sible. 
I ’ve always heard that a good social rule is to assume children are NOT invited unless they are specifically included. 
Please comment. Sign me — Not Running A Day 
Care Center 
Dear Not Running; I agree with you. 
By now, you know who the offenders are. if you invite them again, tell them it’s an adults-only evening and to please make arrangements to leave the children at home. 

Än n 

Lan d ers 

 sages. Yet some people think we are social se­ cretaries. They give us 
“ messages” as long as letters. 
Why don’t they realize there are other callers besides themselves? It is impossible to give good service if 1o calls are waiting and one person takes too long. 

Telepho ne 

Dear Ann Landers: 
I am one of the many hotel telephone operators who work at a big metropoli­ tan hotel, and our switchboards are always very busy. 
During certain periods of the day we are run crazy with all the lines going at once. It’s impos­ sible to lake long mcs- 

Dozens of hotel opera­ tors will be grateful if you will ask the public to show a little considera­ tion. And please, if it takes us a while to answer a call, don’t say, 
“ Oh, you’re there! I thought all of you had died.” — Griped
