Dia g no sis brig ht fo rM.D.s 

By SUSAN BOE 

There may be so me co nfu sio n at the Ho lco mb ho u se when so ­ meo ne asks if the do cto r is in. 

That’s becau se bo th Henry and Jean 
Ho lco mb will beco me M.D.s du ring gradu atio n cerem o nies fo r the UT 
Health Science Center at 3 p .m. Satu r­ day in Lau rie Au dito riu m. 
The Ho lco mbs are o ne o f two co u p les in the 119 member class gradu ating fro m the medical scho o l. 
Henry will receiv e his dip lo ma first, bu t chau v inism has no thing to do with that—his name co mes befo re Jean’s alp habetically . 
The co u p le to o k a break fro m a week o f celebrating to reflect u p o n the last fo u r y ears o f balancing m edical stu dies with a marriage. 
“Witho u t q u estio n, mo d scho o l is easier when bo th the hu sband and wife are inv o lv ed,” co mments Henry , with no hesitatio n. 
Jean agrees, “ Yes, it was p retty neat. I think medical scho o l wo u ld hav e been m iserable witho u t him 
(Henry ).“ 

Needless to say , medicine has been the do minant to p ic o f co nv ersatio n in their marriage the last fo u r y ears. 
“Du ring the p re-clinical classes, we discu ssed it co nstantly —o v er su p p er, with friends, at breakfast, ev ery where. 
Henry wo u ld be in the sho wer and y ell o u t a q u estio n. 
“He still nev er tires o f ‘talking me­ dicine,’ altho u gh I enjo y discu ssing art o r literatu re. Of co u rse, that ties in with my p sy chiatry interest,” Jean relates. 
In retro sp ect, the co u p le feels their main p ro blems were do mestic like: 
Who ’s go ing to do the lau ndry ? 
Jean brags that Henry is a “su p er do mestic” and willingly shared the lau ndry , cleaning and co o king cho res. 
“ If I had a macho hu sband, there might hav e been p ro blems,” she say s. 
Desp ite a shared p assio n fo r medi­ cine, the Ho lco mbs o u tside activ ities 
(when there’s time) are v aried. Henry enjo y s cy cling, handball and p ho to ­ grap hy while Jean likes art, literatu re, mu sic, jo gging and ro ck dancing. 

Cha lleng e 

Chica g o 

The two met at Rice Univ ersity and married the su mmer after gradu atio n. 
Jean receiv ed a research fello wship at the Univ ersity o f Chicago where they sp ent the first y ear o f marriage. 

“Du ring that time I decided to be a do cto r” ’ Henry ex p lains. That was 
Jean’s decisio n, to o , and bo th ap p lied to medical scho o ls in Tex as. 

Altho u gh Jean felt co nfident bo th wo u ld be accep ted, Henry admits they made so me alternate p lans. 
Any wo rries were u nfo u nded fo r bo th gained early accep tance at the scho o l here. 
As members o f the class o f ‘77 the 
Ho lco mbs attended classes to gether, had labs to gethers, went thro u gh the wards to gether, and stu died fo r tests to gether. 
Mu ch o f this to getherness was thro u gh cho ice. “We o ften sat to gether in classes becau se o f alp liabelical arrangements, bu t ev en when seating wasn't assigned. I'd sit nex t to Jean. 
After all, who else wo u ld I rather sit by ?” Kenry smiled. 
Within this su p p o rtiv e rather than co m p etitiv e env iro nm ent, the Ho l­ co mbs u su ally sco red within a few p o ints o f o ne ano ther o n tests. (They wo u ldn’t tell who was the better stu ­ dent.) 
“Whenev er there was a flu ke and o ne sco red mu ch higher, we’d bo th feel bad,” Henry rep o rts. 

Altho u gh the Ho lco mbs hav e su r­ v iv ed the demands o f medical scho o l, the challenge has o nly begu n. 
Bo th hav e been accep ted fo r intern­ ship s at the 
U niv ersity o f f’hicago —their first cho ice. Henry will begin his internship nex t week, bu t 
Jean has p o stp o ned her internship fo r a y ear. 
“The first y ear is the wo rst. We'd nev er see o ne ano ther if we were bo th interning at the same tim e.” Jean ex p lains. 
The internship -residency lasts three y ears. Then Henry ho p es to sp ecialize in internal medicine with a su b-sp e­ cializatio n in endo crino lo gy fo r ano ther three y ears. He’ll then p u rsu e a career in academic medicine. 
.lean’s interests are in p sy chiatry , which also means ano ther fo u r to fiv e y ears o f stu dy . 
Once their scho o ling is co mp leted, bo th will be able to co ntro l their ho u rs better than p hy sicians in general medicine. “The ho u rs will be lo ng, bu t at least they ’ll be mo re p redictable,” 
Henry ex p lains. 
Different 
Op timistic abo u t the fu tu re, Henry say s, “ It’s v ery help fu l we ha\ e fu nda­ mentally different interests—mine in p u re medicine and Jean in behav io r. 
We’re no t co mp eting to learn the same info rmatio n.” 
Do they hav e a p rescrip tio n fo r o ther co u p les sharing the rigo rs o f p ro fes­ sio nal scho o l? 

“ It’s cru cial that y o u really be go o d friends.” Gu ess that’s ju st what the do cto r o rdered!

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS— Soturdoy Moy 28 197 7 
Dining in 'Old Kentucky Ho me’ 

Stra in o f the lo v ely so ng written by Ste­ phen Fo ster ca n be hea rd thro ug ho ut the g reen ho rse co untry o f Kentucky . 
“ M y Old K en tuck y 
H o m e ,” in s pire d by a be a utiful old m a n sio n n e a r Bardstown, is now the s t a l e so n g of K en ­ tucky — and the favorite of many of its people. 
Southern living, espe- 
, eially dining, has always been elegant, and K en­ tucky boasts of its homes and all the furnishings inside. 
Beautiful Federal Hill, the home which inspired the w ell-know n F o s te r ballad, is typical of the 

 mansions in the state. 
In s id e , gleam in g silver, spa rk lin g g la ss­ ware and fabulous foods- adorn the tables. 
A favorite entree for an easy but e le g a n t 
Kentucky com pany din­ ner is duckling. One duck serves four diners nicely; a brace serves eight. 
Wise eooks keep a brace of duckling handy ill the ir f r e e /c r s so the y ’re ready for easy but elegant company or family dinners. 
Menu 
The d uck lin g can be cooked outside or inside; barbecu(‘d or oven roast­ ed. It m ay be served w hole, halved or qua r ­ tered. 
. m 

A B a rd s to w n d in n e r s ta rs 
H oney 
G lazed 
D uckling w ith P ec a n 
Cornbread Stuffing. 
Fresh fruit laced with 
Grand M arnier (served with toasted wafers( be­ gins the feast and is fol­ lowed by the duckling, spiced peach halves and typically Kentucky vege­ tables. 
New potatoes in cream sauce and either green beans or turnip greens with bacon are Southern treats. Even a vegetable salad blends beautifully with the rest of the din­ ner 
Truly Southern breads, perhaps butterm ilk bis­ cuits or Sally Lund bread, d elight hom etow n r e s i ­ dents as well as visitors. 
B ulterballs. straw berry preserves and assorted pickles add glamor and good taste. 

So uthern living , esp ecia lly d in­ ing , ha s a lwa ys b een eleg a nt a nd Kentuck y b o a sts o f its ho mes a nd a ll the furnishing s insid e. 

And, for dessert, old- fashioned fruit c re a m ta rts! Coffee or dem i- tasse and after dinner li­ queur complete this m e­ morable meal. 
Ho iiev Gla zed 
«1 
Duckling with Peca n 
Co rnbrea d 
Stuffing 
1 frozen duckling (4% to 5 pounds), defrosted 
» 4 teaspoon salt 
14 cup honey 
I 4 cup bourbon. If de­ 

 sired 
1 cup sliced celery t/4 cup chopped onion 
^4 cup butler or m a r­ garine 
2 cups crumbled corn­ bread 
2 cups i> 2*inch) bread cubes 
J 2 cup chopped pecans 
Wash, d rain and dry duckling. Sprinkle neck and body cavities with V 2 teaspoon salt. 

P re pa r e glaze. C om ­ bine honey and bourbon if used; bring to sim m ering stage; set aside. 

P repare stuffing. Cook celery and onion in butter or m a r g a r i n e un til tender, but not brown. 
Add bre a d s , pecan s, re m a in in g ^4 teaspoon s a lt an d V 
4 cup of r e ­ served glaze or 2 table­ spoons each of honey and water; toss lightly. 
Stuff duckling cavities loosely. Skewer neck skin to back. Cover opening of body cavity with alum in­ um foil; tie legs together loosely. 

Place duckling on rack in shullow roasting pan 
Bake in slow oven (325 deg ree) until m eat on drumstick is very tender, 
2 to 2Vi hours. 
B rush d uckling with glaze or honey several times during last 3o m in­ utes cooking lime. Serve w ith spiced pe a c he s. 
Makes 4 servings.

__ isAYELLE \, h^.*SAYELLE \ iSAYELLE 1 ^ 

By JANE BLBRICH 
Ex press-News Food 
Editor 

Ta ke a lo o k a t this 
“ g irl nex t do o r.” 
She is an adolescent, and her family is on wel­ fare. 
Her weight is not quite right for her height. 
She has a health prob­ lem that requires a spe­ cial d ie t, but she is hooked on junk foods. 
She also m ight be an alcoholic, a drug addict and/or a smoker. 
And s he ’s prone to anemia. 
But look again. 
She is pregnant. 
Is she re a d y for he r first pregnancy? Or IS it her first? 
And w hat is the c o m ­ munity doing to help her prepare for delivering a f ull- te r m , n o rm a l, healthy, happy baby? 
“ M o the rs a re m a d e , not born, from a n utri­ tional standpoint,” notes one d o c to r who is in ­ volved w ith public health. 
Dr. William .1. McGan- ity is c ha irm a n of the 
Department of Obstetrics and G ynecology at the 
University of Tex as Me­ dical Branch, Galveston. 
He was one of four speakers at the seventh annual National Dairy, 
C ouncil Food W r i t e r s ’ 
C onference held at the 
G alt H ouse H otel in 
Louisville. 
1 2 to 2o 
The subject was “ E at­ ing Your Way from 12 to 
2o,” and Dr. McGanity’s topic was nutrition needs of the ad olescent, w ith partic ula r em phasis on the nutritional problems a s so c ia te d w ith r e pr o ­ duction. 
“ T he pun chlin e.” he says, “ is ‘When is the obketric patient at a nu­ tritional risk ?"’ 
Of the conditions m en­ tioned in the hypothetical profile above, age is a critical factor, he points out. 
F am ily planning pro­ g ram s have not had the s a m e im pa c t on the 
“ m inority teen-age but sex ually active fem ale” tha t the y have had on other reproductive-aged women.

DR. WILLIAM 
McGANITY 

 by women less than 
2o years of age, say s Dr. 
McGanity. 
“ There are four or five segments to the problem of the nutritional im pli­ cation to pregnancy,” he adds, looking at age from another angle. 
"T he most im portant s e g m e n t is how m any years have passed since m en arclie 
(o n set of menses. 12.3 years on the average).” 
F ro m a biological standpoint, he ex plains, 
“ If more than five years have passed, there is no o bs te tric a l d iffe re n c e between her (the adoles­ cent who is preg n a n t) and a woman 25 or 3o years old.” 
If those five years have not passed, however, age thro w s her a n o the r curve. 
She is still growing! 
Because she is econo­ m ic ally d e prive d , she m ay not be getting en ­ ough food even though calorie requirem ents in­ crease during growth to m e et the d e m a n d s of tissue synthesis. 
And, of course, she just may not be getting the right kinds of foods. 
A risk 
“ Who is a nutritional risk? When I see two or more low biochemistries 
(low hem oglobin. V ita­ min A deficiency, etc.) in the sa m e in d ivid ua l,” notes Dr. McGanity. 
Also be c a us e of he r age. she might not seek medical attention early enough in her pregnancy.

(themselves) to a doctor before pregnancy,” says

This is a vulnerable area for congenital m alform a­ tion.” 

The risk is increased considerably if she has been taking an oral con­ traceptive. 
“ Our position in family planning is that no a t­ tempt to become preg­ nant should be made until two s po n ta n e o us m e n ­ strual cycles after com ­ ing off the pill,” notes Dr. 
McGanity. 
Dr. M c G a n ity ’s ta lk ex plored m any other nu­ tritionally related pro b­ lems, pointing out facts such as smoking depleats 
Vitamin C. 
But he was heavy on the obesity question. 
“ And ladies.” he told his pre d o m in a n tly - female audience, “ it is your problem . It is not the pro ble m of the m ale.” 

S upe rim po s e p r e g ­ nancy on this condition, and there is an added risk to m o ther and child if diabetes has developed. 
Also, the n ur s in g m o ther. Dr. M cG anity says, needs an ex tra 1,ooo c alo ries a day for the baby. 
“ if she is not nursing and is going on the pill, she m ust reduce or she will have an ex tra five to e ig ht pounds on her f ra m e for each pr e g ­ nancy.” 

What kind of a diet dues he recommend? 
One that em braces the 
Basic F’our food groups— milk, meat, fruit-vegeta- ble and grain. 
In San Antonio, infor­ mation on the four food g roups, balanced m eal planning and weight con­ trol are available from 
Dairy Council, Inc.

Surv ey 

According to findings from the Tex as Nutrition 
S urvey 
( pa r t of the 
1o-Statc Nutrition Survey in which Dr. McGanity participated), there are ethnic, economic, educa­ tional, medical and den­ tal factors that influence health. 
In the mostly minority fa m ilie s surve y e d , females reached growth m a tur a tio n at 
17 years—but t’neir weight did not sto p c lim bin g then. 
At that age, 14 per cent of the women were more than 12o per cent of stan­ dard weight. By age 35 years, over 5o per cent of the women in the TNS samnle were obese.

Desai. 
Bank say s it didn’t break hiring edict 

National Bank of Com­ merce officials said Fri­ day the Labor D epa rt­ ment has filed a discri­ m ina tion com p la in t against NBC because the bank filed a la w su it against the secretary of labor. 

Both the secreta ries of labor and treasury were named as defendants. 

A ba nk sp okesm a n denied that NBC is dis­ criminatory in its hiring practices and — in fact 
—• that the disputed fed­ eral edict it was ordered to follow discriminated against white m a le em ­ ploy es. 

NBC contends the ex e­ cutive order requires an a ffirm a tive a ction pro­ gram that discrim ina tes a ga inst white m a le em ­ ploy es and that the Civil 
Rights Law forbids d is­ crim ina tion a ga inst a n­ y one. 

The U.S. Department of Labor filed its com ­ plaint a ga inst the San 
Antonio bank for alleged failure to com ply with the government’s minor­ ity hiring rules. 

“ We a re con cern ed that the governm ent re­ gulations in question are th em selves d iscrim in a ­ tory ,” said Robert Seal, 
NBC president. 

Seal said the bank had not received copies of the 
Labor Department com ­ plaint. 

As a result of the com­ pla int, the bank could lose all federal contracts, including serving a s a federal depository . 

In W a shington, M a r­ sh a ll sa id; “ We do not intend to allow this bank or any other federal con­ tractor to circumvent or ignore its obligations. 

$139 millio n 

In 19 7 8 . the bank held more than $139 million in governm ent m oney . La­ bor Secreta ry Ray Mar­ shall said in Washington. 

“ This action m a rks a m a jor step towa rd stren g th en ed en forc e­ m ent of th is d ep a rt­ m en t’s equa l em p loy ­ m ent opportunity pro­ gra m .” 

Friday ’s action was the first tim e the Labor De­ pa rtm ent has m oved to cut fed era l con tra cts from a banking in.stitu- lion over a lleg ed non- compliance with m inori­ ty hiring practices. 

2o days 

The bank has 2o day s to respond to the complaint. 
Fa ilure to respond re­ portedly could result in an immediate loss of its federal contracts. 

“ The bank b elie v es that the Labor D epa rt­ ment’s action was preci­ pitated by a lawsuit that the ba nk filed In D e­ cem ber 19 7 6,“ an NBC statement said. 

That suit, filed in U.S. 
D istrict 
Court here, asked for a decla ra tory judgm ent w hether an e.x ecutive order conflicts with the Civil Rights Act of 19 8 4 that forbids d is­ crim ina tion a ga inst any employ e. 

NBC filed its suit la st 
D ecem ber a fter the 
T rea sury D epa rtm en notified the bank its af firmative action program was inadequate. 
That notification came in N ovem ber and the ba nk w a s given until 
Dec. 18 to submit an ac repta ble progra m . The oank filed suit Dee. 17 . 
It had sought an in junction to bar the go vernm ent from enforce ment pending a trial, but the injunction wa s den­ ied.

San Antonio EXPRESS NEWS— Saturday May 28 19 7 7 
Carters d rive su b marin e 

PRESIDENT J immy Carter handles the controls of the USS 
Los Angeles . Adm . Rickov er is nex t to him 

CAPE CANAVERAL, 
Fit. (AP) — President 
Carter rode a nu clear su bmarine for the first time Friday , took the controls with his wife 
Rosaly nn and drov e it at top speed in a mock at­ tack He said the ship was a sy mbol of Amer­ ica’s military strength. 
“It is v ery cru cial that ou r friends and potential adv ersaries u nderstand that ou r cou ntry is able to defend itself ... with q u iet confidence,” Carter said after disembark ing, wearing a ny lon wind- break e and carry ing hs su iteoat on his arm. 
“ Certainly this ship cou ld v ery well handle cru ise missiles that wou ld hav e a range far bey ond the horizon,” 
Carter said, adding that the missiles cou ld be armed with either nu ­ clear or conv entional warheads. 
He noted that the missiles are central to strategic arms limitation talk s with the Sov iet 
Union. 
The President de­ clared: 
“ The cru ise missile is an integral part of the fu tu re of ou r defense forces.” 
The Sov iets want the 

'Certa inly this ship co uld very well ha nd le cruise 
Id ha ve a ra ng e f a r b eyo nd the missiles tha t wo u ho rizo n

CAPE CANAVERAL, 
Fla. (AP) — Fiv e crew­ men of the .su bmarine that President Carter rode Friday said they were banished from the boat while the com­ mander-in-chief was aboard becau se they ’re too fat. 
The fiv e said they were assigned to temporary du ty aboard another su b­ marine, the Spadefish, and were k ept below, ou t of sight, u ntil Carter left 
Port Canav eral, they told reporters angrily . 
Capt. Lawrence Bu rk - hardt, a spok esman at the su bmarine base here, said the USS Los Angeles did not need its fu ll crew for the Carter mission. So he said, since “we want­ ed to present a good ap­ pearance,” the crewmen ju dged most ov erweight were reliev ed for the day . 
Depu ty White Hou se 
Press Secretary Rex 
Granu m said Carter was told abou t the incident 3o to 4o minu tes before the 
LOS Angeles dock ed after his cru ise. 
Granu m gav e no presidential comment 

 bu t reported that the 
Nav y said some men were remov ed to mak e room. 
O e of the fiv e, William 
Barrendorf, a fire control specialist, said fiv e or six additional Los Angeles crewmen also were deemed ov erweight, bu t were not banished becau se they were need­ ed to ru n the boat. 

United States to agree to limit the nu mber of its cru ise missiles. This cou ntry , in tu rn, wants the Sov iet Union to limit its Back fire bomber. 
Fly ing back to his holiday week end q u arters at St. Simons 
Island, Ga., after the su bmarine trip, Carter told reporters aboard Air 
Force One that Secretary of State Cy ru s R. Vance and Sov iet Foreign Min­ ister Andrei Gromy k o will meet twice more before mid-September on efforts to negotiate a new 
SALT agreement. 
Carter said he did not hav e any specific dates for the meetings. Vance and Gromy k o met in 
Genev a earlier this month and said they had agreed on “ a common framework ” for nego­ tiating a new SALT pact. 
Carter spent three hou rs and 19 minu tes u nder the 
Atlantic aboard the USS Los 
Angeles. He said the .ship operated in simu lated conditions of war and condu cted an emergency drill in which its nu clear reactor was 
“ scram m ed,” or shu t down withou t warning. 
The President said the ship’s officers and crew reacted su perbly . 
Gets p raise 
Carter, in tu rn, won praise for his ship-han­ dling. 
“ With absolu te cer­ tainty . I can say there is no finer ship in the world,” Carter said. “ It strengthened my own confidence in the su per­ ior capability of the peo­ ple who manage ou r v ery 

 cru cial defense mechan­ ism .... I’m v ery prou d of what I see ... Its safety is su perb." 
The su b’s officers and crew, he added, gav e “a demonstration of leader­ ship in its pu rest and most ex cellent form.” 
Carter noted par­ ticu larly that in a simu lated casu alty drill, ju nior officers and crew­ men took ov er the du ties of their su periors withou t a flaw. The President declared: “ I was v ery mu ch impressed.” 
The eommander-in- chief’s onetime mentor and former Nav y su per­ ior, Adm. Hy man G. 
Rick ov er, look ed ov er 
Carter’s shou lder as he handled the su bmarine. 
“ He did a su perb job,” 
Rick ov er said of the Pre­ sident’s performance at the helm. 

Dev elopment 
As a y ou ng nav al of­ ficer in the early 19 5os, 
Carter had work ed with 
Rick ov er on dev elopment of the nu clear su bma­ rine. 
The adm iral said 
Carter operated the su b­ marine’s bow planes and stern planes to gu ide it throu gh the water at high speed. And the President handled the throttle of the nu clear plant when the ship was at top speed. 
Rick ov er wou ldn’t say how fast that was, de­ claring only that it was 
“in ex cess of 2o k nots.” 
He smiled and added that his protege’s achiev ements demon­ strate “that any sailor or officer in the Nav y can become President.”

Mrs. Carter and the snowy -haired adm iral rode the su bmarine into a div e in 1oo fathoms, or 
6oo feet, of water 37 miles off the Florida coast. The su b su rfaced at 3:15 p.m. 
EDT. Carter donned a black cap and fou l- weather gear and stood on the sail as it retu rned to port 

Mrs . Carter 

Side by side, at two balfmoon wheels in an array of instru ments, the 
President operated bow planes and the First Lady operated stem planes as the craft maneu v ered below. 
Rick ov er took a tu rn at the bow plane with 
Carter alongside. At an­ other point, the President took a large stainless 

 steel wheel and guided the boat with Rickov er look ing ov er his shou lder. At still another point, he raised the per­ iscope and peered throu gh it. 
* When the su bm arine reached a depth of 2oo feet, it made a simu lated attack on a U.E. de­ stroy er steaming nearby . 
The President and the 
First Lady ate lu nch with the ship’s crew and 
Rick ov er dispensed with pomp and ceremony aboard. “ I didn’t go aboard to be treated as a high official,” Carter said. 
Did Rick ov er conv ince 
Carter to bu ild more nu ­ clear su bs? 
“I don’t think the Pre­ sident is a man who can be conv inced ex cept by his own conv ictions,” the admiral replied. 
Bu t Carter did note that the nation’s nu clear su bmarine program has cost less to date than the amou nt the United States 

 spent o n its first maimed space flight. At Rick - ov er’s u rging, Carter ad­ ded that the nu clear fleet wou ld be 1o miles long with each ship end to end. 
“ Ou r cou ntry is one that desires peace, and ou r cou ntry is one that desires disarmament,” 
Carter said. He added that nu clear su bmarines 
“ hav e helped preserv e that peace.”

4oo feet most of the time it was su bmerged, said 
Depu ty White Hou se 
Press Secretary Rex 
Granu m, who went along for the ride. He said the v essel cru ised abou t 
45 miles u nderwater.

Saturday May 28 197 7 

By JIM ABBOTT 

AUTO EDITOR 
NAPA, Calif. — If you are witty, more intelligent, friendly, .self-as­ sured, broad-minded, frank, brave and affectionate, then you are the kind of person who will love the new Ford Fiesta. 
William P. Benton, Ford Motor Co. vice president and Ford Division general manager, said research done during the process of designing the Fiesta deter­ mined that mini-car buyers rated themselves as having all of the above qualities. 
Of course, you might even like the 
Fiesta if you are none of the above. The little car — and many people will think it is little — is a real fun car to drive. 
When the Fiesta was introduced in 
Europe only about six months ago, it be­ came an immediate su cce ss. More than 
118.ooo were sold to set a record that no other European car has ever touched in its first six months. 
U. S. debut 
However, tin* introduction dates for the t inted States are still up in the air. Wil­ liam O. Bourke. executive vice president 
— Ford North American Automotive 
Operations, said, “ The Fiesta production impasse is typical of the suspense and melodrama surrounding the auto industry these days." 
The reason the introduction date is not known is that the car has not been certi­ fied by the EPA. Fiesta will be sold as a 
1978 model and since Ford says it cannot meet the current 1978 standards with any of its cars, the Fiesta will not be solitnnti! the ('ongress acts to allow a carry-over of the 1977 standards for a year. 
Right now it seems that Aug. 5 will be the earliest the ears w ill reach the dealers’ showrooms. There are already 
2o.ooo Fiestas on shore being held at ports of entry awaiting certification. 
Adventurous 
The wait until August will be well worth it. The Fiesta is one of the most attractive mini-ears to come ashore, not just in styling, but in tho spirit of adventure the machine imparts to the driver. 
Even those who do not particularly like 

A u to T a lk 
IIv 4 1 »! A b b o tt 
A h i *» t o ll t o r 

First 2oo-m. p. h. lap established at Indy 

FO RD’s Fiesta is a m ini-car and a real fun car to drive 

 been made as easy as possible Front disc brake wear can to cheeked without re* moving Ih»' wheel, as cun the rear drum brakes 
To help cut down on operating costs 
Fiestas are equipped with Michelin radial tires for very long servici* and extra gas mileage. 

The magic 2oo mile an hour lap was turned at Indianapolis this year for the first time by pole-sit- ter Tom Sneva. 
Sneva clocked one lap of 299.535 during his qualifying run. If the qualifying speed is any indication, this could be one of the fastest 5Q9’s in history. 
The high speed is the result of several factors including better and larger tires, excellent aerodynamics, the newly resur­ faced track, good weather Conditions and 
Sneva’s Cosworth V-8 engine. 
The Cosworth engine is the latest deve­ lopment on the Indy scene, coming strongly into favor with many top me­ chanics. it could well power the winning car across the finish line. 
A .I. Foyt is also running a V-8, his ow n 
Turbo Foyt/Ford. which he continued to refine and develop after Ford elected to, get out of the auto race engine business. 
Foyt uses the V-8 engine to power his 
Coyote, and he is still given a very good chance of taking home all the bacon at 
Indy. 
Impressive group 
There is still an impressive array of the venerable Ott’ys in the 33-car lineup. The ancient engine has been refined, boosted, evolutioni/ed and revitalized to where it is still a threat. 
In theory. at least, the V-8s should have an advantage over the four-cylinder 
Otfys. USAC rules say the Indy ears must have a 1.8 mile per gallon fuel consump­ tion. 
The therotieal advantage lies in the fact the V-8s, with their small bores, can run on a leaner mixture at a given amount of boost than the Offy, und so go faster on less fuel. 
It is an almost unbelievable turn of 

:ZAUJQmamiQMW 
_ 

 the nun bear concept have expressed a 
'feeling the ear is really fun to drive The lBOOce engine, transversely mounted, and supplying power to the front wheels through a trans-axle, supplies ample acceleration. 
The Fiesta will go from zero to 5o miles an hour in 9.5 seconds, and equally im­ portant, it will brake from 59 to zero in only 4.3 seconds. Front disc brakes are, standard on all Fiestas. 
Rack and pinion steering allows the 
Fiesta to he driven rapidly, with imme­ diate response in traffic situations The 
Fiesta is also stable on the expressways. 
Test drives 
Ford says Fiesta is a car that has to be driven to he appreciated, and lest drives by potential buyers will be a strong part of the advertising campaign when the car is introduced. 
The Fiesta comes in several stages of trim, from tin* standard model to the 
Gina, hut in only one style. The two-dour hatchback design is the only model of 
Fiesta that will lie offered. 
Since the ear has not been certified, there are no official EPA mileage figures available, but Ford estimates the Fiesta will get about 42 miles on the highway, 33 in the city and a combined rating of 37 
Walter Hayes, chairman of Ford of 
Europe, says the Fiesta was designed so the yearly operating cost would be held as low as possible, and that gas mileage is not the most important factor in overall operating costs. 
Easy serviceability is one outstanding feature of tin* Fiesta Ford even puts out a small service manual for the do-it-your­ self owner who wants to save as much money as possible. 
Many items of regular service have 

A FEW SECO N D S is all th at’s required to “pop the to p ” on this i 9 7 7 D o d ge Aspen 
Lar makers turn interests to tops 

Air conditioning 

Air conditioning will be offered on 
Fiesta, but 9 will be installed after the car is shipped to this country, either at port of entry, or at the dealer 
The air conditioning is built by Eaton, and the installation is through the dash vents. The units will only In* installed on models that are equipped with the heavy duty package. 
Ford expects to sell 199, 999 Fiestas a year in this country, with alt of them be­ ing supplied by the German Saarlouis plant. That is also a selling point for the ear — German engineering and quality. 
There seems little question that Ford could easily sell more than the 199,999 
Fiestas they plan to import each year. In fact, Hayes said the entire European pro­ duction of the Fiesta could he sold in 
Europe without exporting any to North 
America About 19. 999 Fiestas will lie sold in C anada. 
Benton said the reason the ear cannot bo introduced to the public is because of what Henry Ford 11 recently called the 
“ fiddling and rumbling" in Washington in response to a question, Benton said if 
Congress does not carry over the 1977 emissions standards then Ford will have no choice hut to shutdown and not produce any 1978 model ears, it could happen. 

SPECIAL TO THE EXPRESS N EW S glass is tinted to coordinate or contrast with the roof color and inside there is a manually operated fabric sunshade to in­ clude or exclude the sun’s rays as de­ sired. 
If anything has slowed the dominance of vinyl roofs, it has been the emergence of 
T-Bar roofs. These have a metal bar down the center of the roof and removable translucent panels over the driver and the front passenger seats. 
T-Bars are as close to the old-fashioned convertible as is available in U.S.-built passenger cars and they may become the preferred roof option. 
Dodge currently offers T-Bar roof op­ tions on its Aspen and Charger SE mo­ dels. 
Still another trend likely to grow stronger is the tendency to add luxury even though size, weight and horsepower are going to be subtracted in order to meet federal regulations. 
Adjustable steering columns, stereo tape players and speed regulating devices all gained in 1979 as compared to the number installed by the factories in 1975. 

DETROIT — Its what’s on top that counts in rmw car options for 
1977. 
A last fling with big cars slowed a pre­ dicted consumer switch to smaller en­ gines and other economy-motivated op­ tions. But, there was no slack in their interest in colorful alternatives to the now obsolete “ rag top,” more formally known as the convertible. 
Nearly half of all U.S.-built cars had a vinyl roof in one of the varied styles available in 1976: canopy, landau, halo or full vinyl. 
In addition to these varied effects and the array of colors available, they also offer the alternatives of sun roofs and 
“ T-Bar" roofs. The latter consists of two removable translucent panels inserted in 
• he muf over the front seat, while the former is a sliding section of the roof itself. 
Another wrinkle being offered on the new Dodge Diplomat is a tinted glass, power operated, sliding sun roof. The 

Regs a problem 

SPECIAL TO THE EXPRESS N tW S 
The steel industry must comply with 
5.6oo seperate federal regulations in its decision making, reports the Council on 
Wage and Price Stability. The Automotive information Council queried two major car producers who indicated they were so busy complying they haven't bothered to add up tiie regulations. It’s certain the auto figure would be many times the steel total.

Properly tuned car saves owner money 

INTERIOR of Graham mobile home which features energy saving insulation package 
Plastic revolution 
Both the (iiMuiyear Tire f'o and Ford 
Motor C’o. predict tluoe xxill he twice as mueh plastic used in cars by the 19K!i model year. The rubber m anufacturer predicts four ol every 1o ears xxill wear 
" sott” front and rear ends that xxon't scratch or dt'iit by 198o. 
Ford says it xviil be consuming more than a billion pounds of plastic materials annually by 198o. 
I’hicf reason for the trend is the need to meet government mileage standards that euli for 271/2 m iles per gallon for <*ach inamifaeturiTs fleet average by 1985. 

SIfClAl TO THE EXPRfSS NEWS 
Keeping your car pronerlv lumul can saxc you money time and aggraxation. 
An improperly tuned ear is hard to start bucks, jolts and stalls out m the early .going and xixastes gas—up to one gallon m six. 
How do you knoxx when your car needs a tune-up? 
Here are five indicators. 
Miles drixen 
Car manufacturers list tune-up interxals in the owner’s manual. 
Each car is different. Some may not run effieienlly for as long a pt'riod as the manual states; some mav be efficient over a longer period. When you approach the interval suggested by the mamifueturer 
Energy saving pushed in m obile hom e 

Energy conservation is a m atter id concern for the buyer of a mobile home, as much as it is for the bnxer of any new home. 
And the mobile home industry is re-i sponding to that concern. 
P restige Mobile Hom es, 19H3 Austirit 
Hwy., is featuring energy efficient mobile homes. The energy package includes in­ creased insulation and storm windows. 
' 
I.anchart Industries uses the Ow'cus*. 
(Mirmng package in its Lancer and (ira- 

 ham m odeb, both built in Texas and sold by Prestige Mobile Homes 
The <-ost of providing the energy con­ servation packages ranges from $5o9 to 
$1,ooo per unit. This increase in price seem s to be accepted by buyers 
Changes in construction of the energy efficient hom es includes 2” x B” w all studs to allow for six inches of insulation in the walls and 13 inches below the roof for sufficient insulation there. 
These insulation ft*atures (xvhich exceed 

 federal standards) can result m energy sax trigs to the home owner of 51 to B4 per cent. 
Since there is very little that can be done to add insulation to older m obile homes, the buyer should know' before he buys just what he is getting in the way of insulation. 
Bob Sim pson, m anager of P restige 
M obile H om es, can explain how the 
Oxvens-Corning package will pay off year after year in savings for the owner. 

 for your car. be alert to the kind ol 
{M'l'formance you're getting. 
Ciiis mileage; It's a go« » d pruetiee to keep records on the miU's per gallon .xour ear delivers. When this begins lo decline, a tune-up is in order. 
Hard starting; If ,xou have (rouble starting your ear. the [intblem is likely to lie in the ignition sxstem . Be certain, hoxvever, that you are following tin* start­ ing procedures prescribed by the manu- faetliter before you conclude the car needs xxork. 
Hough idling: This is a sure sign (hut 
.xour car needs a tune-up. If the ear is not tuned It gi'nerally won’t operate smoothly xvhile idling. 
Acceleration: Lnxx eomfiression engines ind emissinti control devices make it impossible for a relatixely new ear to delixer instant response, but all ears can and should provide a smooth, iinmter- rupted eiimb during heavy acceleration. 
If your car doesn’t, it nei'ds a tuno-uj>. 
Apart from avoiding the inconvenience and annoyance of a car that xvon’l start or stalls repeatedly, the motorist xxho keeps his car tuned up saves money. 
It costs a typical motorist motorist $4o to $5o in wasted gas to drive 5,ooo m iles with a poorly tuned engine—which is the price of an average tune-up.
